Be warned though.... YOU MUST CALL IN YOUR ORDER IF YOU ARE IN ANY SORT OF RUSH.... Q takes his time and is no master of efficiency, the food is worth the wait, but unless you feel like waiting 30-40 minutes I would call in ahead of time....
author: Sam K.

description: The best classic subshop in the city. A 6-inch avocado sandwich will have TWO AND A HALF avocados on it - seriously, the only legitimate avocado sandwich in my eyes. In addition to being simply delicious, the owner is a great character - super nice, stern, and definitely never lets anyone else handle the food at all. Watching him slice avocados is amazing. Such style. Warning: can be quite the wait so call in your order ahead of time.
author: Rita C.

description:
It's good, fresh just not great.  Oh I won't lie, I still order it because its close by and a decent alternative to other local subs in the area.  Prices are fair. Line is always long so do yourself a favor before you go down there and queue: call ahead and give them a good 15-20 minutes before you roll in.

I'm a fan of the hot italian beef with all the goodies on it.  The meat is stewed for a few seconds in that delicious brown sauce before its tossed into a soft roll and given a makeover with all the trimmings.  Get the 10", it will feed you tomorrow and a fair value at $8 bucks.  Jalapenoes are free as an addition so slap em in if you like it spicy like me.  I have had their Atomic sub; its good but at $15 I just dont see the value.  Its a blend of beef and pastrami with all the other stuff you like.  I'd rather just stick with the beef or go pastrami if thats your thing...hell get both seperate and blend them at home!  It will be the same price and double the food!  Other than that, pretty standard, chip rack, range of sodas and I believe beer, but dont quote me, I never eat in, always to go...speaking of which, time to go pick mine up.
author: Mark C.

description:
Best sandwich in Northern California.  Done.  

The submarine is wonderful.  The meatball sandwich is gorgeous.  And if you want avocado on your sandwich, you'll get tons of it.  

Yeah, don't wait in the line for 5 minutes only to get to the front to decide what you want, he's got sandwiches to make and he shouldn't have to wait on you when you get to the counter because you wanted to talk about your Walk of Shame to your vapid friend.  (Talking to you, Marina Girls).
author: Rick D.

description: Cash only was really a drag as we had to buy the cheapest sandwich (with bologna and ham).  Meh.  The place was cramped and not very clean.  You also pay a lot for not much sandwich.  The owner was super nice and accommodating though.  Perhaps we'll try again, but for now we're fans of The Sandwich Spot nearby.
author: Kim K.

description:
Let's table the fact that I can only stand being in Cow Hollow for about an hour max before I start to feel punchy with the annoying white chicks with the "omgs!!" and ugly gucci purses and talk about a sandwich. 

Now I enjoy a good sandwich but I can be kinda picky. I want to see where my meat is being sliced, freshly ripped pieces of lettuce and huge rounds of cheese. This place is not that but the avacado hook-up, toasty bread and secret sauce kinda make-up for that.

 Like other folks said I would order ahead or be patient and wait but beware those damn prepsters.
author: Jade W.

description:
On a short weekend trip to SF and staying in The Marina, so decided to find me a good local sandwich shop.  You really get any more local than this place.  Old man owner making the sammiches while his young teenage employee rings you up and takes phone orders.  

I ordered the Italiano and it was exactly what I had imagined it would be.  Plus it was TOASTED!!! It's cold here in SF and the toasty bread hits the right spot.  

Since the owner takes a lot of pride, he makes all the sandwiches it seems.  While this ensures high quality, it makes waiting there unbearable.  I read in an earlier review to call in the order, but since I had never been there I decided not to.  Well I'm glad I didn't call in the order, because there were 7 call-ins and they seem to make the in-store sandwiches first, so less waiting for me.  Not sure if this is the case everyday, but on a Saturday at noon, that's the law of the land it seemed.  

I'm now going to enjoy my food coma :)

Thanks Marina Submarine!
author: Eric N.

description: toasted sub sandwiches.  it was delicious and the medium size is huge!  i don't know what they put in the sauce but it makes a yummy sandwich.
author: Animal K.

description:
Checked out Marina Submarine at 1PM on a Saturday.  I'd heard gripes about the line, and had my to-go order ready in 20 minutes.  Yes, longer than your average sub shop, but worth the wait (I had the signature: The Submarine).

The owner / sandwich-builder, Kyu, is very efficient at his craft, and puts on a knife skills clinic with his mound of California's freshest avocados.  Top marks for freshness of ingredients, bread quality, portion bang for your buck (tough to find in Cow Hollow), and the pickle!

I'll definitely be back to try some of Kyu's other creations, namely the Italiano, the Cheesesteak, and the Meatball sub.
author: Nicolas T.

description:
The bar was set pretty high for this place as I had heard nothing but good things and I am a sandwich lover but my expectations were met.  I got a large and thought I could finish it but no way.  The Italiano was great and the "secret sauce" was awesome.

I love how the owner is the only one that can make or even wrap the sandwiches though.  Kinda felt bad for the cashier.
author: Blake B.

description:
Pros:
Great tasting subs..
I've never seen anyone slice an avocado so fast....

Cons:
4 people in front of you = long line/long wait
Subs tend to be stuffed so they fall apart.
1 guy making the subs
author: Angelica C.

description: Good ol' fashioned sub. I got the turkey with avocado and it was great. They don't skimp on the avocado at all. I ended up getting a medium and it lasted me 2 meals so I can only imagine how big a large is.
author: yoni s.

description: Yes the hours are limited and it's cash only, but Q is nice and he makes great subs.  I usually get the meatball, Italian, or turkey/avocado - all are great!
author: Bud L.

description: On the north side of town Marina Submarine is the best! Not fancy and only open for lunch but just delish! I love the sub with everything... wish I had one right now! It's cash only so come prepared...
author: SF G.

description:
Walking by this shop, the distinct aroma of toasted sandwiches flows out the door and into your nostrils. That's a good sign already. 

So we walk in, and there's this girl behind the counter with glasses who looks like she just woke up. We tell her we want a small Atomic and she stops me and points at the man behind some curtains rearranging some boxes. I'm confused as to what's going on. The man comes out a bit later, Korean male, average late 40s to early 50s and he asks what I want. I was kind of expecting the girl to tell him what I wanted since I just gave her my order but she just stood there and stared off into blank space. So I repeated to the gentleman what my order was: a Small Atomic sub. He goes up to the girl behind the counter and tells her "Small Atomic Sub." Mind you, this is the third time she has heard it. And she stands there almost as if her brain was running on 64MHz and then it's like "ding---Process complete" and then she slowly punches in the price on the register. It was pretty amusing. 

The sandwich itself was good. The bread is a bit thinner than those found at Gene's Liquor or Submarine Center and didn't hold up to the moisture too well. The pastrami was excellent. There was a generous amount of meat and the "special sauce" was standard to the previous mentioned stores. 

However, one major gripe is just the cost itself. A small Atomic with tax rang up to be about $9.35. That's crack prices! A LARGE with Avocado at Gene's is less than that from what I recall. It's heinous that a large here without avocado runs about $14 and change and with tax probably closer to $16. Even at Submarine Center, their largest SUPER is only $8.70. Maybe it's because I'm on Union Street, but nonetheless. Expensive sandwich with borderline retarded staff is enough for me to consider the tantalizing aroma as a stench.
author: Derrick L.

description: Stop whining these sandwiches are so good. Service is slow because he doesn't need to hire anyone else because no one else could make the sandwiches so good. He really loads on the avocado and all the veggies are delicious. A little pricey if you add the avocado but so good, my favorite sandwich in the city.
author: Kenny J.

description: This is my favorite sandwich spot in San Francisco. The guy who makes the sandwhiches is so nice. I always get the cheesesteak sandwhich and it's amazing. The line can take a while most of the time
author: Paul B.

description:
I arrived at 1:49 PM with the hopes of trying this place out. I had heard great things about their sandwiches. I waited in line for what seemed like forever. I finally got my food at 2:34 PM. Yes, that's a 45-minute wait in line! I'm a patient guy, but waiting for 45 minutes is only tolerable when the employees are working hard. One employee just stood and watched while the other did all of the work.

The food was great. The turkey sandwich was delicious, and loaded with avocado, but honestly... no sandwich is good enough to wait in that line again.
author: Greg B.

description:
I can distinctly remember my first bite of an M. Sub, as my family has taken to call the place. Heaven. Easily the best submarine in SF. My first bite was in 1991 so I know what I am talking about.

Note for first timers: If you have seen the Soup Nazi ep of Seinfeld, that is kind of what Kyu (the owner) is like. Only answer when spoken to. He doesn't care if you don't like mayo when he is asking you if you want it toasted. Tell him about the meat and cheese and he will take it from there in the order that suits him best. Trust him, he's an artist.
author: Christina C.

description: For a hole in the wall deli that only accepts cash, this place is amazing. I had a double meat - roast beef and turkey - medium sandwich and it was delish. Even though they were out of sprouts the bread was perfectly toasted, and all the ingredients were very fresh. They scoop the avocado right in front of you. There are also homemade meatball subs and lot's of salami, ect. For a heavy, fully loaded sandwich of this caliber I'll pay $9 anyday.
author: Nate S.

description:
I think I probably ate 2 avocados today. I think that crazy workout/climb I had earlier was probably a good thing. 
My friend turned me on to this place and suggested calling ahead to the order the sandwich so that there would be no long line waiting. She was right. 
The line was long but our sandwich had just been made. I was kinda sad to miss the avocado show and see exactly how much was on my sandwich....
The sandwich (avocado and cheese) was toasted and melted  to perfection. The special sauce really was that special and made the sandwich. It was a messy, gooey sandwich; just what I like. 
My "new" fav sandwich spot but I don't think I need anymore avocado for awhile...
author: Kelley D.

description: Convenient sub shop in the Marina, but if you don't have a lot of time, you might need to consider going somewhere else. When I went in, there were 3-4 people in line in front of me, and I was easily standing there for 10-15 minutes before my order was taken. That being said, the sandwich was delicious, and you definitely get your money's worth in terms of portion.
author: Amanda R.

description:
This place for some reason makes a really good sandwich. 

I feel like the person who made it took extra care with the sandwich. He placed each filling so carefully and didn't cheap out on adding the avocados.

Overall it was a good experience and the setting is great. If I want to hang out at the Marina my ritual would probably be to grab a sandwich here and then walk to Crissy Fields and munch on the sandwich as I look at the Golden Gate Bridge/People watch =)
author: Michelle L.

description:
BOMB!!!

I love sandwiches, could eat them for every meal.

Make sure to try the Italian. And don't be a weenie, get the LARGE. If you can't finish it, which is a hard thing to do unless you're starving, take half home and save it for later. Add avocado too and watch him dice it up. But don't get too chatty.

AND THEY HAVE ANCHOR STEAM!
author: Mike B.

description:
Tried this place out because of all the good reviews. I ordered the Italiano. The people who work there are very nice. The subs come with fresh ingredients and the roll is toasted. I ordered a medium and it was big enough to make me wonder what the large looks like. It was really very good and the price reasonable ($6.95). I asked for jalapenos, and, boy, i got them, aplenty. Luckily I didn't mind, but be warned.,

The only dig I'd give on the place is that the wait was long. I only had 4 people ahead of me and I waited 15 minutes before I was able to order.  There was only 1 person making the sandwiches. Nice guy, and a good multi-tasker, but...

Also, I wouldn't say its the best sub place in S.F. I would give Lucca's that nod. Especially if you like your subs more Italian than "American".
author: Rich M.

description: Rude people, dude makes sandwich without gloves on. And way too pricey for a sandwich!!
author: Kelly B.

description:
We stumbled upon this place after having ran the Lyon Street Steps. We walked in just to see what's up and what this place serves, and we were WOW-ed. The sandwiches the man (goes by "Q") was making looked extremely delish!! The set up is kinda like Submarine Center but Marina Submarine is a 2 man operation: one man (Q) makes the sandwiches and another man rings people up. 

The sandwiches here are delicious but let me warn you about their size. If you're familar with Sub Center's sizes, let me do a quick comparsion:

Marina Sub's SMALL = Sub Center's CENTER/SUPER
Marina Sub's MEDIUM = Sub Center's SUPER (if not bigger)
Marina Sub's LARGE = Can feed a family!!

No joke. The deli meat is the same, toppings, etc, but Marina submarine loads on the avocados and their bread is slightly chewier. I ordered a MEDIUM and quickly regretted it after Q started to pile on the meat & toppings.

Come here hungry & leave rolling out the door...
author: Heidi C.

description: I recently moved to San Francisco, and shortly found Marina submarine.  The sandwiches are the best, but the preparation is entertainment to the max.  I love this place and highly recommend it.
author: Dave H.

description:
It's difficult to argue with a humongous sammie loaded up with fresh veggies, topped with sauce and toasted for only $6.50. 

There are three sizes of subs, all of which seem to be ample. Traditional turkey, pastrami, roast beef, avocado or just cheese subs will keep things simple, while satisfying your hunger. The line can be a bit cumbersome, but tolerable. 

No frills. Just large toasted subs, coke products and chips. Veggies were super fresh and I love that they have sliced jalapenos for a little kick. Take away is perfectly acceptable, and (personally) preferred since their chairs and floors look a little grungy.
author: Theresa T.

description:
After a few hours of climbing at Planet Granite, everyone was craving something good and quick.  While not the fastest service at a sandwich shop, this place certainly was goooood.

Walked into a simple store with a couple of tables, put our things down and got straight into the line that was starting to build up.  Sadly, they ran out of hot pistrami, so I went with a Turkey Avocado sandwich.  I think they threw in a whole avocado which was pretty awesome!  I went with the large and got a few lookers wondering what I was thinking.  They've never seen me eat before.  That 10" sando was pretty hefty, but I put it down now problem.  A good amount of it spilled onto the tray, but I made sure to eat it up.

Nice place to stop by when you're in the area.
author: Tom Y.

description:
One of my favorite sandwiches in San Francisco.  Everything about it is yum, yum, yum.  

2 key points to note: 1) they come really large, so be prepared 2) there is only one guy who has the honor of making these sandwiches is SLOOOOOW, so be prepared to wait... or order ahead....
author: Addie N.

description:
sandwich nazi? hardly.

the sandwiches here are simple and with high quality ingredients. both the sandwiches i bought to split with a friend were toasted. probably the best sandwich on union street.
author: Ameer N.

description:
I finally found ONE reason why I love working on Union st! Two words : Marina Submarine

Such a small sandwich joint that's so popular around here! I can't believe after 6 months of working here, I finally just made it here. AND I work right across the street! It's not the cleanest looking place but the hole in the wall places are the best places to eat and has the best food with a cheap price next to it. There's three different sizes. The small is about $5 and the largest is about $7-8? Don't really remember since I only paid less then $6 for a sandwich here.

While I walked in with just one person in front of me, 2 minutes later, a line was formed behind me, and as I left, it was fully crowded! Poor man (owner), he's the only one working the sandwich line and there were way too many orders for him plus so much phone orders! One person ordered 9 sandwiches along side 5 other phone order tickets and 20 people in line! Poor guy, as long as he doesn't drip sweat into my sandwich, I'm good.. 

The turkey avocado and cheese sandwich was toasted on a soft roll with plenty of their special spread, lots of whatever condiments you liked, PLENTY of turkey slices, and unlike a lot of other deli spots, LOTS AND LOTS of avocado. I swear, he sliced his avocado so precise and perfect, he just placed probably more then half of an avocado on the baby. I had chunks of fresh avocado all through my sandwich. And for around $6, I had two meals!!!

Bad thing, they take cash only and I usually only have credit cards so when I DO have cash and is working here, I go grab myself a big scrumptious sandwich! Just remember to come early before the lunch rush!!
author: Juliane N.

description: BOO-YAH.  This place rocks. The unemotional sandwich artist/owner is a controlling genius. He cares about getting your order EXACTLY right, and the only way to do that is for him to do it himself, I could watch him make sandwiches all day long.  (the teenager who works there is only allowed to fill drink orders, answer the phone, and ring up purchases. The wait can sometimes be long, but ALWAYS well worth it. Go for the Italiano, heated, with everything. MMMMMMMMM-MMMMMMMMMMM-GREAT.
author: Amy W.

description:
Love this place! For value and an amazing sandwich, this is your place. As stated by the other reviewers, if you are a fan of avocado's it doesn't get better than Marina Sub's! You literally get an entire avocado on your sandwich. The bread is toasted to perfection and everything is super fresh.

If this is your first time, it can be a bit confusing with their random sign that doesn't really provide any indication what sandwiches are available. There is also an awkward silence exchange with the cashier, because she doesn't take the orders, the owner does. Its actually kind of entertaining to watch people stumble in not realizing this place has a reputation of deliciousness and turn around and walk out because of confusion.

Calling ahead is probably the best if you don't want to wait in line.
author: Wendy W.

description:
This place was once part of a local chain of sub shops, until the owner sold them off 25 years ago.  Of those, only Marina Subs and Submarine Center still use the original menu, and of those two, Marina Subs gets the edge, for softer and flakier bread, and for truly masterful construction. No one, not even you, will ever care about your sandwich more than this man.  I once asked him if he ever let anyone else make the sandwiches and he said, "There was someone ten years ago. Customers complained. Never again."

He is not the Soup Nazi.  He is the Sandwich Ninja.  

Order the Italian Combo with avocado and cheese, you'll see why.

Cash-only, obviously.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Fact: Came to San Francisco for 5 days and ate at Marina's 2-3 of those days. 

Bring a book, a knitting project and throw in a Gameboy for good measure because boy, you are in for a longggg wait. Everyone has the sandwich pangs at the same time of the day. Also bad timing for us, someone had just ordered a HUNDRED sandwiches right before we arrived and since the owner is the only one to touch the sandwiches, it took ages before the line budged. 

He remembered my friend's order from 3 years ago when she visited every day after high school which is freaking astounding. Boar's Head meats, the freshest ingredients and a god-given sammich artist who could put SubwayQuizno's out of business if we could manage to plant a clone of him in every major city. 

One commandment when inhaling one of this man's subs: thou shalt not waste the special dressing. When consuming the first half, open up the face of the second half below it so it can "catch" all the dressing from the piece you're currently eating. Then everyone is happy!
author: Faith Y.

description: This place is probably one of the best sandwich places I've been to. It's one guy making all the sandwiches which I gotta give him props because it does get pretty busy. I'd give this place 5 stars if they didn't only accept cash but really that's not a big deal, also it is a bit pricey but you get what you pay for... a good sandwich.  I always order a turkey sandwich and what I love most is that avocado is only an extra dollar more and he is NOT stingy with it!!!!!
author: Sam G.

description:
pretty darn good. not the best ive ever had though.
special sauce wasnt 'out of this world' 
the workers were very friendly 
the place is really cute. 

(only had a sandwich but id like to come back and try some soup..)
author: Lisa N.

description:
I will fully admit that I get annoyed easily by rude people. You don't want to be that guy that stands too close to me on the bus or the girl who takes the elevator up one floor and causes the rest of us to be late. 

But get this! Even after the Marina Sub Nazi barked at me to move over because I was apparently standing one inch too far to the left at the counter, I am STILL giving the place four stars. 

It's also ridiculously slow and not all that clean - both very important things to me, but I still obsess over this place. Trust me, that is saying a LOT.

My go-to sub: A small, turkey with swiss, avocado, lettuce, tomato and special sauce.
author: Carolyn C.

description:
I don't always give five stars, but when I do, it's incredible.

Get the avocado.  At no other place will they give you a full avocado on a sandwich for $1.  
My staple is the pastrami with avocado.  Try it, you'll be glad you did.
Oh and call in before so you don't have to wait in line.
author: Andrew K.

description: The subs are awesome. If you like Avocado on your sandwich be sure to add it on here. They will put at least 1 while avocado on your sandwich more than I've received from any other sandwich place. The secrete sauce is great too. Bottom line give it a shot.
author: Scott L.

description:
I tried Marina Submarine for the very first time and was sorely disappointed. The prices are reasonable but sadly I likely wont ever return here at will any time soon.
I ordered my usual  favorite: (simple) Turkey Breast sandwich and was so bummed out. The sandwiched lacked flavor and personality. The bread was nicely toasted but the ingredients, although (somewhat) fresh didn't really bring anything to the table. I felt like I could have made this sandwich myself had I just hauled my ass to the grocery store & picked up lettuce, tomato & onions. In fact I KNOW I could have made a MUCH better sandwich and I'll even add in an even BETTER secret sauce(!!)
I didn't order cheese or extra toppings because I was hoping their "secret special sauce" would be enough to satisfy my submarine craving. It totally FAILED. The sauce was too watery and was more or less just salty water, w/ olive oil, vinegar and some random Italian spices thrown in. The sauce was so watery it basically soaked the toasty bread and made it super soggy which just made me turn into Oscar the Grouch w/ a long faced ugly pout... 

I SO wasn't prepared to eat a crappy sandwich on such a beautiful sunny day... 
:(

I will NOT be coming back...!

Oh & FYI, 
The Sandwich Spot 
www.sandwichspotsf.com
        & 
Ike's Place @ 3489 16th St. IS SOOO MUCH BETTER!!
author: Karen G.

description: Best Submarine Sandwiches in San Francisco, in my opinion.  Great quantity and quality for the price. Parking is terrible, though. You'll be lucky if you park within a 6 block radius.
author: Josh J.

description:
Last night I dreamed I was eating one of their perfectly toasted sandwiches (pastrami and swiss, everything but mayo).  This time though, there were avocados.

p.s. Cash only.  
p.p.s. there is hardly a wait if you go on weekday before 12:15pm.  After that, you might wait anywhere from 5 minutes to thirty minutes (i've never eaten here on a weekend so I don't know how long the wait is then.)
author: Tangerine L.

description:
Four 1/2 stars due to small selection.

I never heard of this place until today.  I was walking around the Marina today and wanted to pass by my dearly departed Great Aunt's flat on Pierce Street.  It's yellow shingle, versus the dark brown I remember.  I wonder if the house still has her "lazy Buick" installed?  As I was crossing Union Street, I saw this line out of a corner store with "Submarine" on the awning.  I couldn't pass this up, as the line was out the door.

While waiting in line, I could not decide from anything on the menu, even though there's only about 8 sandwiches to choose from.  I chose to get 2 of the Italiano, which has three kinds of meat.  (mortadella, salami, capicola maybe, and provolone).  While the menu does not say the subs come with mustard, everybody who ordered one did.  It was actually pretty good, and give it a good spice.  I would never think to have mustard on an Italian sub, but this might change my mind.

Al subs come with tomato, onion, lettuce, "secret sauce", mayo and mustard.

Anyway, it rivals any sandwich I've ever had.  Maybe a list is in the making?  The subs are toasted in a Bakers Pride oven.  The large is 10" long, but I wonder what they do with the left over two inches that's cut off?  Who's going to order a 2 inch sandwich?  

The guy is the fastest I've ever seen pitting and slicing an avocado, and laying it neatly in even slices on some sandwiches.  Less than 10 seconds, and it's all done.  Perhaps he worked at Benihana in a previous life?

Cash only, and vegetarians will have only one option.  A Sprout and Avocado sandwich, with all the trimmings.  I honestly felt some kind of euphoria after eating one half.  The other half is in the fridge right now, and NO, you cannot have it.
author: Michael M.

description:
Best Subs/Sandwiches of any kind in town! The man behind the counter is about as high quality as you get in life. I have been eating at "the sub shop" for over 15 years of my 23 year life and I have yet to be let down. Good selection, quality ingredients, perfectly toasted bread, and the secret sauce have kept me coming back for years. Just order avocado and watch a master at work. I take all of my friends here and I have never had a friend make a negative remark. Enjoy.

You know a place is good when people come on Yelp for the express purpose of tearing a place down and complaining about how "they've had better." The service is slower because you have an artist making a sandwich. Don't go to Danko or Turtle Tower and bitch about the wait.

If you come here on a sunny weekend day at lunch time you are going to have to wait. It sucks, but it's just how it is. The guy is a legend.
author: Sven S.

description:
Actually, it is NOT worth the wait!  The OWNER/SERVER makes his sandwiches after counting cash and operating the register without WASHING his hands.   While customers wait, he lambastes the 14 year old clerk for "not charging for cheese".

The reason the wait is so long is because this prick is too cheap to pay for more minimum-wage help.  Ever heard of "Marketing Myopia"?  This guy can't find anyone to work for him.

After completing this review, I am filing a complaint with the San Francisco Health Department!
author: Hank S.

description:
Just moved to the neighborhood.  The apartment?  Windows don't open, rats in the walls, and no closet space.  The selling point?  Two blocks from Marina Submarine!

These are the best damn sandwiches I have ever had!  Although I have tried about 2/3 of the menu, I cannot seem to convince myself that there is anything better than a regular, Turkey, Swiss, Avocado, with lettuce, tomato and sauce.  

The amount of avocado that goes on a sandwich is incredible.  My GF gets an Avocado Sandwich, which is the only all veggie sandwich.  A small gets two whole avocados!  

Yes, on certain days there can be a wait.  Big Deal!  If you are in a hurry, plan ahead and call it in.  No Place Better!
author: Hugh B.

description:
Being from Philly, I knew I would have to forfeit some things when I moved to the west coast: great pizza, Pat's cheese whiz cheesesteaks, and of course, good italian hoagies...or so I thought.  

What? You don't know what an italian hoagie is?  If you want to get some idea, go to Marina Submarine and get the italiano sub sans mustard. (Mustard on an italian?  What's up with that? -1star)  Whenever I get homesick, that's what I do.

Their rolls are the best in the city and the guy that makes the sandwiches has it down to a science! Pickles are great too!
author: Erin L.

description:
This is a fantastic place to get a sub if you ever find yourself in the yuppiest part of the city.  It's a total hole in the wall, but with a solid selection of sandwiches and a freezer full of gelato.  There are only two choices of bread (white or wheat), but each sandwich comes in 3 different sizes ranging from 5" to 10" (maybe it should be Castro Subs, hmm?).  The ingredients are all fresh and your sandwich comes absolutely STUFFED with them.  In fact, if I have one complaint it's that they slightly overstuff your sub, making it somewhat difficult to eat.  But that's tough to bitch about when you're eating a nicely toasted sub stuffed with meat, veggies, and a whole (!!!!) avocado.  Yes, he slices up an entire avocado and puts it on the large sandwiches, which are plenty big for two people to split.  

To sum up:  Big, tasty, toasted subs and gelato.  Oh, and they serve beer.  Keeper.
author: matt c.

description:
So this owner dude does it all.  Yeah, the lines can be long.  The wait can run a clock to dead batteries.  But still, the sandwiches are always fantastic.

What trips me out is owner-dude has like 2 or 3 helpers but nobody ever, EVER, gets involved in the sandwich making process.  The help answers phones, or rings up customers, or just watches the samurai warrior at work.  Seriously...he weilds his knife like a sword, he cuts his avocado's with precision.

My fav is the "cooked" pastrami with avo & jalepenos.  I'm not talking about Louis Rich pastrami.  This guy cooks it daily and it usually runs out by Noon.

They are pricy but if ever a sandwich was worth the dollars, this is it.  Keep swinging your deli-knife you bad ass sandwich making warlock!
author: Pete M.

description:
Do you like sandwiches?  Do you like them so much you will wait 25 minutes in line for a soggy Hoagie not even that loaded w/ Turkey Roll, Avo and some squirted on special sauce that ain't so special?

Bullcorn.  No one should like sandwiches THAT much.  

Ooooh, I gave the beloved Marina Subs a 3 star.  Oooooh....  Watch me get blacklisted.  Ooooh... I am so afraid.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I've been known to get in a car and drive all the way over here from the Financial District during lunch just to get one of these subs.

It's a testament both to the yummy goodness of Marina Sumarine as well as the total shitfest that is the Financial District as far as great subs go.

Either way, It's f'ing good.
author: Matthew R.

description:
In a city where great sandwiches are not among the finest foods San Francisco has to offer, Marina Subs brings the game to a whole new level, putting the City by the Bay on the sandwich map.
I've been coming here for 24 years. It's hard to say what makes Marina Subs sandwiches so good-- the meat is great consistently, tomatoes are among the freshest in the entire city, melted cheese is heavenly, and the not-so-secret sauce rounds out these gems-- but all I know is that when I meet people from outside San Francisco who once resided in SF, I ask them "do you like Marina Subs?" Their answer determines how cool they are. 
Plus, I generally see people with whom I went to high school when I go here, which is both a bonus and a drawback.
In short, freakin' amazing.
author: Ross S.

description:
After reading about all the hype and only trying the gelato floats here..I decided to try their subs!
Luckily Sunday during lunch, there was not a huge line and we only had to wait just a few minutes for the "master sandwich  maker" to take our order and make our subs. 
I tried a small Atomic sub that had massive amounts of meat along with mayo, lettuce, and onions (I declined peppers). The Atomic was very good, my boyfriend commented on the good quality of meat which I could also taste. Sub had alot of great flavors and was definitely fulfilling even for a small size!
A small Atomic cost $7.95, but was well worth it for the size and quality. 
It was funny coming here since I told my boyfriend to just order and not try to make small talk with the sandwich maker so he could focus on what he was doing. When he tried to the guy nearly ignored him and continued only making sandwiches, haha.
Wouldn't mind returning if I was in the area
author: Miss H K.

description:
This place is great, the man behind the counter has got the whole scene dialed.  The consistency is so good b/c only Mr. Marina Sub makes these beauties.  What you get is:

a.  A lunchtime line ranging from 'bearable' to 'i need to start thinking of excuses to tell my boss b/c i've been in line here for 45 minutes'
b.  The most avocado I've ever seen on a sandwich in my life if you dare to order it.  (I saw someone get a veggie sandwich, including 2 1/2  whole sliced avos on a single sandwich - sheesh)  Just know what you're getting into, that's all.
c.  One of the best sandwiches I've had in the city.

Some comparisons to the soup nazi are inevitable as there is a fairly specific routine and the sandwich artist can come off as gruff, but it's all part of the experience.  Occasionally I see people rehearsing what they are going to order before they step up, not a bad idea if you get stage fright.

Great prices, helpful brodies running the cash register, this place can't be beat!
author: Mike B.

description:
So I have been to Marina Submarine a few times now, and I have enjoyed it. I have been very lucky, in the fact that when I have been here it has not been too busy. Place is pretty simple and seating is pretty tight, so I usually like to just grab my sandwich and  take it home.  
FYI, Cash Only!
author: Lisa A.

description:
I usually prefer not to eat sandwiches on the weekends because I eat them pretty much every damn weekday; however the bf had a craving and wanted to try this place out. I refused to order a sandwich and decided to get a cup of yogurt nearby instead. When we got home, the medium sized italiano sandwich he bought was massive...whoever made it stuffed the living crap out of that sandwich.

I went on to take a bite since the yogurt wasnt too satisfying..that one bite ended up being half the sandwich..I would have eaten the other half if he hadnt finished his yet..it was LITERALLY the BEST sandwich I have ever eaten in my life...no joke...
author: M W.

description: I grew up in Philly, so I have higher expectations than most, but the logo "the best subs in the city" was a draw.  Unfortunately, these guys just throw meat on bread...  Horrible.
author: C F.

description:
I've been going to Marina Subs since I was about 10, maybe even younger; I just can't remember. I absolutely adore this place - the sandwiches are simple, tasty, fresh and never change! Maybe I'm just nostalgic for those days we used to creep away from Hamlin and get a sub. Either way, it's not to be missed if you are looking for a good toasted sandwich. 

Just one little issue - the lines can be terrible. If you don't want to wait for 40 minutes for a sandwich you either have to eat lunch at 3pm or you'll have to find another spot.
author: Zoe K.

description:
It's tough to score a decent sando in this city, and especially difficult to find a sub place that knows how to make a great hot turkey with melted swiss. 

See, I like my turkey subs with all the fixins', particularly with some oil and vinegar on top. However, if the bread is too toasted, it can't absorb enough of the oil and vinegar, so it ends up getting all over you and your clothes. Oil is a steely bitch to get out of clothes. In fact, I don't think it's possible. 

Marina Submarine does a quality, top-notch job of balancing toast action with proper O&V dispensation.  Solid. 

Be warned, however, this is THE stop off point for a number of middle to high schoolers after they get let out back onto the streets. You can expect a good, long line if you get the timing wrong in the afternoons. 

My only complaint / suggestion is that they should post their phone number on their shop sign so, if you happen to be driving by looking for a parking space, you can call in your order to save time (see above paragraph re: those krazy kids).
author: Hannah Q.

description: So so so good. My two sons have lived in the area for a few years and every time in in town, they want to go here for lunch. If you love avocado, this is your spot!
author: Tami G.

description: Ate here today. My friend who's been coming here for over a decade brought me. Long line but worth the wait! An exercise in patience is not the worst thing. Watching the guy make a sandwich is like watching art-mesmerizing. And they are not stingy with the avocados! My turkey avocado was delicious and it's just what I needed. Have definitely added it to my list of go-to food spots in the city!
author: Jilleen l.

description:
THE BEST SANDWICHES ANYWHERE!

I used to live catty-corner to Marina Sub and can honestly say these are the best subs I've ever had.  My favorite was the cheese steak (not traditional, but roast beef and cheese).  The owner is truly a sandwich artist!  I now live in Southern California, but I make a point to hit Marina Sub anytime I'm back in SF.
author: Jason F.

description:
There is nothing (and I mean nothing) better than a sunny Sunday afternoon at the Palace of Fine Arts, watching brides decked out in design travesties taking wedding photos, while munching a sub from here and telling yourself over and over again that you will never, EVER, make your bridesmaids wear lavender.  Seriously.

I could watch Q cut avocados all day long.  He doesn't even look down at the avo when he's cutting it.  EVER.  its mesmerizing.
author: Erika C.

description:
I must pay homage to the Sub Nazi! He is a perfectionist. His sandwiches encompass the perfect ratio of veggies to meat to cheese all hugged together with crusty bread that's crisp, but doesn't tare your mouth apart. 

I see this guy every morning setting up his store with meticulous care of all the produce and meats. Say what you want about his repremending. If you want perfection, then get with the programe.  Everything is consistent and strategical placed. I think the only thing that changes is the register guy. I can't imagine they last very long.
author: Erin M.

description:
My guy went to grammar school at a Catholic church up the street and swore this place was heaven.  

We strolled past his old school-yard as he recalled his boyhood days of mischief.  When we reached the door of Marina Submarine, the line was about 3 deep.  We also realized a sign that said "cash only" so we wandered down the street to an ATM.  By the time we got back, the same 3 people were there--along with another 2 or 3.  One of us should have just waited there!

Yea, the wait was long.  But the guy who put together the sandwiches was great.  Not personable, maybe, but really attentive.  There's just the one guy doing the sandwich and a kid running the register.  Most of the time, people are just waiting for the sandwich guy and the kid looks like an ass milling around on the side doing nothing.  Not his fault, I guess.

My turkey sandwich was good.  The special sauce, while not super special, does seem to make the sandwich.  One note though:  the roll gets VERY toasted.  So toasted, in fact, that the roof of my mouth was ripped for a week.  I need to remember to make a special note of that the next time I go (I've forgotten the past few times).  

I think it's good.  I don't think it's great.  Don't try to park nearby.  Definitely stop by though.
author: Melissa Q.

description:
This is definitely the most non-marina joint in the marina. What? No black puff vests in line? Well it was raining, guess they needed the protection of sleeves. 

Maybe I give this place a 5 star rating because I was really hungry like a new born for the milk of a teat. Maybe I was caught up in the moment while sinking a sub in the rigors of battle. Wait, the sub was last night's dream and I had my teat milk earlier that morning, made from powder of course. 

Yeah, now I remember... It was the scrumptious river of homemade tomato sauce flowing down the sides of the mountainous meatball sandwich like molten lava spewing from the Sicilian volcano Mt Etna. The tasty sandwich roared. Tangy tomato sauce poured down the  slopes of the soft sweet roll and threatened the safety and crispiness of my chips below that were bracing for the worst like the villagers of Nicolosi, but my cheddar sun chips did not run as they wanted to bask in that explosive goodness too.
author: Michael R.

description:
Here is the deal.

I would give this place 10 stars if I could. This is definitely a place where you will come hungry and leave very VERY happy.

Atmosphere:
Your typical look sub shop except these guys serve beer. Bonus. The Sub Master behind the counter is always there slinging subs- he works at his own pace so you have to just go with it. 

Suggestions:
Come here at least twice. 1st time, you have to experience the pace of the Sub Master and be a witness to his expertise. The wait is long, so be prepared. You will be satisfied.

For the 2nd time- CALL AHEAD. You get the great taste without the long wait. Give it about thirty minutes before you pick up.

Parking:
There is none. Bus 45 takes you there or drive with a partner so they can jump out and pick up while you circle.

TIPS:
Go next door and get a cupcake for dessert.

Don't pay attention to anyone who gives this place less than 5 stars. 
Yelperific!
author: Aaron A.

description:
Been coming here forever. Great food at an even better price. Portions are huge, fresh food, tasty and fulfilling! Best deal in the marina. Worth a visit. 

Check your attitude at the door. If you are too important to wait that long for a sando, then just call ahead and it'll be ready when you get there. Don't expect anything fancy. It is what it is, a good plain deal on good plain food.
author: Nick B.

description:
Delicious! I especially enjoy the Italian Combo, which is a perfect blend of   meats, including salami, plus your choice of cheese, lots of sauce (Italian?), all of which is toasted to perfection.

I believe there is ONE and only ONE guy who makes the sandwiches here. (To ensure taste and quality?)

Better to phone ahead, or you might cry.
author: Tina J.

description: Best subs in Marina.. Don't miss it! Beat the lunch HR lines ..
author: Avi S.

description:
I came here today around noontime after hearing that this was THE best sandwich shop EVER. It was definitely very delicious and very hearty. 
As others mentioned, there was a line but it moved along efficiently. They use quality ingredients and are incredibly generous with the portions. 
Size references:
Small - 5"
Med - 7"
Large - 10"
but to me the large seemed even bigger. I think it may have been the biggest sandwich I've ever had.
Three things that makes Marina Submarine stand out FAR beyond their competition:
-the man behind the counter making the sandwiches is like a ninja swordsman artist all wrapped into one. He uses 1 knife for everything (watch him slice up avocados, you'll find yourself staring in awe) and is truly the sandwich master.
-avocado! I saw him slice, scoop, and set an ENTIRE avocado plus some on my sandwich. fantastico, i tell you!
-bread was not soggy even after dressing. Over saturating the sandwich in dressing making it soggy is one of my pet peeves. The italian dressing here is addictingly  good and the best thing is that enough of it is used for sufficient flavor, but it doesn't feel doused leaving a perfectly crispy (soggy-less) bun!
Nom nom nom.
author: Patricia S.

description: Please go right now!  People have recommended this place to me for so long, and I am mad  that it took me this long to try it out.  Definitely add avocado and cheese, it is so worth it.  The bread is so soft and warm and fresh.  The italian dressing they put on it is divine.  Go now!  I promise you'll enjoy it.
author: Caitlin B.

description: If you want to wait a million years in line then this is the place to go. There is only ONE sandwich maker and I swear he never smiles. Even if there is only one other person in line in front of you, be prepared to wait at least 10-15 min. Granted, the sandwiches are good but I'm not one to wait especially when I'm hungry. Sandwich maker NEVER smiles but the cashier person is really friendly.
author: A W.

description:
I eat here 3 times a week MINIMUM with my homie Nick Bea.

Here's all you need to know:  Italiano. BOMB. tuna. BOMB Meatball. BOMB. Roast Beef. BOMB. Turkey. BOMB MOTHER ******.COM

Hands down addictive. stop complaining about the wait and call ahead trolls. This is the best damn sandwich you've ever had.
author: Natalie S.

description: good stuff.  cash only though.  no printed menu, but i uploaded the pics.
author: Isabella F.

description:
Holy Underwear!

Finally a good sandwich shop in SF that doesn't cost $10 or more.  And I mean you get more for what you pay.  Get anything with avocado in it, the sandwich maestro will throw in a whole friggin avocado across your sangwich.  In my book, that means love, my friend. 

I can't give this place a 5th star though, cuz the line is ridiculous, anyone who orders by phone gets priority, and they didn't have any chicken salad.  You're lucky your sandwiches are good, damnit!
author: Zo L.

description:
Walking down Union St. to Steiner, you can smell a mix of meats and sandwiches roasting. Right there on the corner is a small shop covered with primary red and yellow paint. (It looks more like a hot dog stand or Ronald Mc Donald's house on the inside.)  On one side of the counter is where the sandwich magic happens and the other is where you pay. 
Yes, the girl at the counter is half out of it, but overall genuinely friendly. They need those signs that say "order here", "pay here" because I had no idea I was supposed to tell the guy what to make instead of the girl at the register. 

My order: A medium(7")  Italiano sandwich with peppers and everything else. This was by far one of the best subs I've had in a lonnnnng time. They are most generous with the meat and the sandwich tastes fresh, unlike some places where I think I'm eating ingredients that have been in a freezer for half a year. 

Beware: The sandwiches can be a bit messy, so don't wear white or take a date here.
author: Sherese E.

description: Full disclosure: I've been coming here for over 20 years so this review is possibly subject to extreme bias colored by nostalgia. Here's what you should know. This place makes fantastic, no nonsense, non-gourmet, traditional deli subs. I've read peoples' gripes about the ambience. It's a deli. It's not Bouchon Bakery. I've read their gripes about the service. Don't go for the service. Go for the awesome sandwiches. I've seen their posts about the soggy bread. It's a sub. They put dressing on subs. Dressing is comprised of 97% oil and vinegar. Here the other 3% is comprised of pure, delicious magic. Dressing makes bread soggy if you attempt to take it to the Marina Green to have a picnic. Don't take toasted subs with dressing very far away to enjoy. But DO get yourself over to Marina Submarine for some tasy, tasty toasted subs. And don't forget to add the avocado!
author: Sebastian L.

description:
Marina is a good place for subs.  my friend Dan calls sandwiches sarnies-- so i will call them that too.  he is British and of course everything is different on the other side of the pond.  i must say i love the sarnies in England--nicer than the sarnies in the US.  but Marina Subs is a good place for a custom made sarnie. 

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
More of an icon than a great eating place.  When the line gets out the door you can be in for a 30 minute wait.  You can't rush the master though.  Just watching him cut the avocado can be worth the trip.

I'd warn against the atomic sub for anyone on the fence.  you have to be seriously prepared to down that thing.
author: jeremy S.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised when I rolled into Marina Submarine and realized it had the exact same menu as Submarine Center in West Portal! Woo woo!

But I do have to admit, I was a bit disappointed. Fairly predictably, I ordered the hot pastrami sub. But this pastrami had SO much fat on it - at a certain point, I just began stripping the fat off. Ew. My friend informed me that some people like the fat...I suppose I'm not one of those people.

Whatever that special sauce is that they use - keep it up! I'll still be going back, but maybe I'll opt for the turkey sub next time. 

Oh yeah - they're incredibly generous with the avocado!
author: Dalia K.

description:
This place is what Quizno's goes to bed and dreams about becoming when it grows up.......if it's lucky.

The bread is top notch, they don't skimp on the meat, and the sandwich is toasted to perfection.  I refer to the guy who makes the sandwiches as the "Sandwich Ninja".  If you've ever been there, you know exactly what I'm talking about.  He wields his ginsu knives and slices, dices, and juliennes.  And don't even get me started on his precise ninja abilities with avocados.......it's a thing of beauty.

The only complaint I've got is since it's only one guy making ALL of the sandwiches, there can be quite the wait, which can be a pain in the ass when I'm in a rush.  But otherwise, this place rocks.
author: Norm U.

description:
You can't beat large traditional subs at cheaper prices than anything else you will find in the area, fresh ingredients (though, simple-- just the basics but they give you a ton of it)-- no fancy ingredients like different bread choices or specialty cheeses/meats, but what they do have works fine.

It seems like the owner/sandwich maker won't let anyone make sandwiches so the line gets really long and moves incredibly slowly during lunchtime.   Cash only.

Great value and taste!!
author: James B.

description:
Every time I come in here I see nothing has changed except for the skinny high schooler behind the register relegated to that area. That is comforting for sure. Q is not only an artist but a friend. He remembers my order (and makes fun of me for not getting condiments, etc.)  and asks how my family is. I had never tried coming here prime-time on a weekend but recently I forced myself to put the number in my phone because the wait was excrutiating. No problem. It's worth it to me. 
I think I've had the same sandwich here for 16 years or so. I think I can now move to a different one. I've heard the meatball and hot pastrami are money.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Ridiculous knife skills, get in line and watch this guy cut avocados and pickles.

Expect to wait 1 hour plus for a sandwich, but it was worth the experience.
author: Chris A.

description: Best Avocado Sub in the City.  Hands (drenched in special sauce) down.
author: Alex T.

description:
I am a Marina Subs convert...

I never liked this place...thought the sando's were soggy and plain...the trick is to forego the sauce (or get it on the side) and put on your own mustard when you get home...unless you like the plain yellow kind.  

Now Im a huge fan...great sandwiches and theyre reasonably priced...but dont expect to get any exotic combos...its pretty much a turkey, ham or salami kind of place...
author: Ken S.

description:
Go-to sandwich: small turkey sub with provolone, avocado, jalapenos, and everything except mayo (everything = lettuce, tomato, onion, mayo, mustard, italian dressing).

Cost: $6.94

Pros: 
- Toasted!
- Avocado madness - he puts an entire avocado in your sandwich
- Loads of lettuce, tomato, onions. It's like getting a side salad.
- Big and filling
- They have a bunch of copies of The Onion

Cons:
- Bread is nothing special
- Overstuffed; sandwich often falls apart
- Whenever I ask for "a little bit" of jalapenos, I always get a ton of them, so I stopped asking for "a little bit" and end up picking a bunch out before eating my sandwich.
- The wait can be heinous if it's busy. I suggest calling ahead.
author: Ranjit S.

description: Five Stars for the FOOD....but 3 Stars for the LINE. Here's the deal with this place. I've been going here for 16 years. It's one of the best sandwich places in the City. BUT....there is NO help for the owner, just him cutting avocados about as slowly as one can possibly cut an avocado. Typically just one stony high school kid, who runs the cash register, helping this guy out. He is SO nice, but so damn slow, it's painful. What this means to you is that you will wait 20 minutes for a sandwich, but it's a damn good sandwich...all of them. Toasted bread, home made meatballs etc.
author: Dan F.

description: These sandwiches are awesome. My wife brought me here after telling me for a long time how great this place was. She was not lying. The owner makes every single sandwich himself and it shows how much he cares. The food is awesome, prices are cheap and the portions are huge. I always get a sandwich from marina subs when go up to San Francisco
author: Adam M.

description:
The only reason they don't get 5 stars is because of the customer service. The older Asian man pretty much threw my sandwich at me, but it was still an amazing tasting sandwich. 

I ordered ham and cheese. It was very good. The pickles were .50 cents extra, but once you realize how many pickles you get you'll understand. They are amazing. If you're a wheat fan like myself you're going to have to settle for sliced bread, but not to worry it's fresh. For $8 you can enjoy a small sandwich, bottled drink, and chips... very affordable for the Marina district. 

So don't expect the best customer service, but do know that you'll leave happy. 

Cash only! 

ps. if the young guy that works the cash register reads this please note that you were very nice. I'm talking about the "master" sandwich maker. Poor guy.
author: Shel Z.

description:
Best Sandwich I have ever had.  Use the bathroom before you go, because they have none.  I had to duckwalk over to Rosies across the street and use their restroom.

When I cam back my Italiano was ready.  I'm more of a turkey guy...but this concoction of salamis and Italian cheeses was delish.  I saw ridiculous amounts of meat, avocado, etc...going onto other sandos being made.  This place is epic, and very cheap considering the amount of product that is going on the sandwiches.
author: Joe C.

description:
I'm a big fan of italian subs so when I saw this place, I thought ...oh yeah! This is going to be great! I go in and I saw the lay out of cheeses and meats and thought to myself, I'm going to probably have a tummy ache after I leave here and it's going to "hurt so good"...well first the attendant just stared at me for about 4 minutes, didn't acknowledge me, just stared as if he didn't want me there, well too bad buddy I want a sandwich, so finally he decided to take my order and I told him what I usually liked, he said I should try the Italian Combo, so despite the subpar service that I received up to that point, I  decided to listen to the guy. He gave me a sandwich with beef and sausages that was just YUCK~

Just a couple bites and I didn't even want to stay, I needed to buy some chips to eat and get the sandwiches taste out of my mouth. I'm usually known for giving a restaurant several chances but the subpar service and sandwich has sunk any chance of me going to this submarine shop again.
author: Troy R.

description:
Hands down best subs I ever had. Yeah the wait is long if you just drop by, but I personally dont mind waiting for a 5 star sub at all.

Subs are fresh and delicious.

Girl behind the counter is such a sweetheart and is relly helpful.

The guy who makes the sandwiches is wicked with a knife but also really friendly.

tip: call in order- it helps.
author: Jynni T.

description:
This quite possibly could be the tastiest sandwich i've had outside of Potbelly's in Chicago.  Why are there no potbelly's out in SF?  Ok, I digress.  The meatball or turkey and avocado are delicious. 
Food - 4 Stars
Service - 3 Stars.  Today I placed an order and was told 10 minutes; showed up 15 mins later and the sub was still not ready.   Only one guy in the place is allowed to do anything...and they close at 4!  I certainly be here 2-3 times a week at night if they stayed open.  I guess it helps I live across the street.   If you have a few mins to wait and you are shopping on Union, I would certainly add this shop to your destination list.
author: Ben R.

description:
HUGE fan.  this place makes the best sandwiches, and they're massive.  The line is long, the wait is long, owner isn't the nicest bloke, but who cares?  It's just that tasty.

As for Eric S with, like, the only bad review....time to change your tampon, dude.
author: david s.

description: I came here on a Sunday at 11:30 am and there was no line. Probably because everyone else was waiting for a table at Rose's Cafe across the street for brunch. In any case, I was in the mood for a sub and this place delivered it. I had the turkey breast with the "special sauce" (is that just italian dressing??) on a warm, toasted sub and it was delicious!
author: Helen Y.

description:
I love the way this guy abuses his teenage labor.  He won't let them make sandwiches, and he barks orders at them like they were lesser forms of life.  Quite humorous.

Riddle me this:  How can the sandwich guy work so fast, yet provide the slowest sandwich making experience in the city (with the exception of Rutily's)?

I think he needs to hire me as an ops consultant.  A little que theory and work flow maximization, and he could turn those sando's OUT!
author: Andrew C.

description:
Best sandwiches EVER. Every time I get a tuna sandwich with avocado, lettuce, tomato, mayo and mustard -- toasted, of course. I don't know what Q does, but it is like a magic explosion in my mouth. So tasty, and completely worth the insanely long lunch line. I try to go during off times though, as to avoid the line. 

I have a habit of arriving just after he closes, and I am consistently heartbroken.
author: Elly F.

description:
Best East Coast or West, 
Finest submarine hands down, 
Avocado slicer.
author: Brian J.

description:
Love their meatball sandwich!!!  A must try.

The service is not the best BUT i can deal with it since the sandwiches are too die for.
author: Unique t.

description: This place is delicious! Perfect little hole-in-the-wall sub shop in Cow Hollow.  I only give it 4 stars because the table area was a tad messy and only takes cash. But I highly recommend and can't wait to go back!
author: Nicole M.

description:
Maybe it's because I'm a vegetarian, or maybe its because I really wanted a Freddie's sandwich, but they were closed for the holidays, but my avocado sandwich was better than what I'd find in LA, but SO NOT FREDDIES!!!  

Where are the hard sourdough SF rolls Marina Sub?  Not even dutch crunch?!?!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Fantastic subs, as great to eat as they are to watch being prepared.  The toasted bread, sauce and avocados make it special, but every sandwich stands on its own.  The wait can be long, but it is worth it.
author: Rich C.

description: I've been eating Q's subs since I was a youngin'. He slices avocado like a ninja.  Best subs ever.
author: George P.

description:
Decided to give this place a try after a friend of mine told me he visited it on a regular basis while growing up. I stopped by on my lunch break and watched the owner prepare my roast beef sandwich by adding all my ingredients as if there were no tomorrow and toasting my sub bread w/ care. I was surprised at how generous he was with the toppings, as most places can be a bit stingey.

Once I was back at the office and had the chance to sink my teeth into that beast of a sandwich, I was in pure heaven. The bread was nice & toasty while still being soft in the middle and didn't include that stanky smell that Subway's subs tend to have. Also, the meat wasn't excessive like Togo's, but was juuust the right amount, balancing out the sandwich toppings.

The only cause for lack of a 5th star is because I tried their chicken salad sandwich the other day and wasn't much of a fan of the chicken since it tasted pretty spongey. I think I'll just stick to their sliced meat sandwiches and will be giving their meatball sandwich a try since it looked mighty tasty.

The ambiance is a bit depressing w/ bad lighting and an old skool menu that has poorly concealed menu items & prices (it looks as though they used random pieces of paper to do their cover-up work). However, I doubt many come here for the ambiance.

This place knows how to get the job done in terms of serving up some dee-licious sammiches! It looks like I'll soon become a regular!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
If you go here, you've got to say hi to Tony, the owner who's been there pretty much my whole life.  Another SF quiz question based here -- what's on the ceiling of Marina Sub?  (Answer at the bottom of this review).  Years ago (like 20+) this was a Mr. Sub, and the sandwich board is, I believe, a relic from that time.

The best things about this place: more avocado than you can shake a stick at (and Tony's the best avocado slicer I've ever personally borne witness to -- watch and learn!).  They've had a toaster oven for their sandwiches since the beginning, before those other el cheapo sub chains even existed, and they use it to good effect.  The cheese is high-qual.  They've got ice cream and a wide assortment of chips including Funyuns.  The classic Sub is a favorite; for a long time in my childhood I also ate Italian Beef regularly.  My girlfriend is partial to the Turkey Avocado.  Oh, did I mention the excellent oil and vinegar dressing they put on the sandwiches?  Drippy and messy but worth it.

If you come in the afternoons on a weekday be prepared to see a horde of local kids from Hamlin, Town, UHS, and Sacred Heart in line, and let me tell you, they don't leave hungry.

Last time I was there, I was eating a huge Atomic Sub in the window and a couple walked by and the guy did a stop-and-stare, head-turn as he walked around the corner, infatuated with my sandwich in a manner usually only seen when a guy is reading an article on Jessica Alba in a bikini on The Superficial.  I almost blushed, I was so embarrassed.  But it doesn't stop there!  He grabbed his girlfriend and popped in and asked me what I was eating, if it was good, and then got in line.

When I think about going to eat in the Marina/Cow Hollow area, this place is right at the top of the list.

Answer to the question at the top: a playing card, I think it's a 10 of clubs but come to think of it now I can't quite remember.  Tony said there used to be another but it fell down, and they were there when he bought the place and he doesn't know much more than that.  I guess I'll have to go back soon and figure out the specifics again!  Lucky me.
author: Walter K.

description:
I'm in awe of the sprouts and avocado.  Not because of any sprouts (the sandwich maker will often forget them), but because of the unreal quantity of avocado they manage to spoon into a sub.

The lines are long and service slow because the owner refuses to let anyone other than himself make the sandwiches.  This leads to high quality and slow speeds.  When it comes to sandwiches this good, I'm willing to wait.
author: Jay S.

description:
this is the one place in the city where you get a really really good sub. The bread is toasty, and the lettuce and onions are so thinly sliced the taste fuses itself with the meat and explodes when you take a bite.

This place is like... sacred sandwich making. There's always someone else helping out at the store but they NEVER touch a sandwich, not even wrap it up. I mean, there must be some rule here where the owner is the ONLY person who ever makes the sandwiches. He's amazing tho, with the ' i can chop avocado with my eyes closed' technique, he deserves the dedicated fans like myself who will stand in a line that's out the door for a...sandwich.

it's really messy to eat, grab a table and sit down. unless you live around the corner, it's hard to resist busting the sandwich out immediately and many times, I've had the overloaded sandwich half on my dress by the time I'm home.
author: Scarlet S.

description:
I'm a closet Marina/Cow Hollow fan, been in denial for a few years now, but I gotta confess to not understanding the hype here.  I grabbed a turkey sandwich the other day and it simply reminded me of a Blimpie sandwich.    Blimpie is an East coast sandwich chain ala Subway, Quizno's, known for it's basic ingredients/sandwich offerings.

The sandwich was perfectly suitable, and I enjoyed the excess of avocado, but the ingredients really were subpar...so, I'm just giving this joint 3-stars as I can't say I'll be rushing to get back there.
author: John R.

description: The sub I got was pretty good!  Happy with the food.
author: Cristina G.

description:
What can I say, I love this place.  I make it a ritual to come here at least once a week.  The prices for Union Street are fantastic.  It's a bit away from all the action but well worth the walk.  The small is enough to fill me up and the large is enough for 2 meals (and I'm a big eater).  Don't be misles by the little diagram he has of a small, medium and large on the wall.  He adds about 2 inches to that length.  The sandwiches are a great deal.  It comes with lettuce, tomatoes, white onions, mayo, mustard and special sauce.  You can also add a few things like jalapenos and of course the avocado.  He puts almost a whole avocado into your sandwich (small) for just a buck!  If you end up getting a large, he puts in like 1 1/2 avocados for the same price.  The special sauce is like a mix of oil, vinegar and some spices.  It's delicious.  If you are taking it to go, I would suggest getting the sauce to go.  Since he toasts his bread, it keeps the bread all nice and toasted when you are finally ready to eat.  

My favorite subs are a turkey avocado, straight salami sandwich no avocado or the philly cheese (which comes with roast beef, onion and cheese).

Some days can get really busy so call ahead if you are in a lunch rush.
author: Ken W.

description:
The toasting of the subs is the key that makes them very good. Don't have them put too much oil and vinegar one or you'll end up with one wet sandwich.

Watch out for the long lines around lunch.  Also watch out for the "sub nazi".  You can't miss him, he must make all of the subs, and make them his way. Keep in line!
author: Dave L.

description: I really wanted to like this place, but the poor customer service here was a deal breaker for me.  I ordered the avocado and sprout sandwich because I had a craving for sprouts.  At the time I ordered the sandwich, the sandwich-maker didn't say anything about not having any sprouts.  I paid the full price for the sandwich and then proceeded to a table.  It wasn't until after I started eating that I realized there weren't any sprouts on my sandwich.  I got back in line and told the sandwich-maker that there weren't any sprouts on my avocado and SPROUT sandwich.  Did he forget, or were there no more sprouts?  He said very reluctantly that he does have sprouts but not at the present time.  Umm...right that means that you don't have sprouts.  I would've expected him to tell me that he didn't have any to put on my sandwich at the time I ordered so that I could have at least gotten something else.  I didn't like the dishonesty and that I was charged full price for a sandwich for which one of the main ingredients was missing.  It's like ordering a turkey sandwich and then not getting any turkey.  Not cool.  As I was leaving, he said that he would put sprouts on next time.  Well, my friend, there won't be a next time.  The sandwich was really good, but honestly I can get just as good of a sandwich at my regular sub place in the Inner Sunset with much better customer service.
author: Julie P.

description:
If Sub Center and Marina Sub had a duel Marina Sub would seriously kick some Sunset N Judah riding ass.  

Props to Q for making the sweetest turkey provolone no tomatoes sub ever.  

Sometimes i see a group of middle schoolers here and it brings a tear to my eye thinking about all the make-out parties that we planned when we were at Marina Sub back in the day.
author: Ryan S.

description:
3 for the avocado slicer man. 
-2 for the 45 minute wait...and the sketchy kid behind the register who I cant decide if I realllly liked or was reallllly annoyed by. He was the only thing to stare at for 45 minutes besides cold-cuts and cheese chunks.
author: Dandy O.

description: Fantastic subs!  Fresh bread, great ingredients. Loved it!
author: Rob D.

description:
This place was the only really good submarine place near my school and my school firneds and I would make the trek as many times as we could to get here, taking two transfers. Within a 45 minute lunch break it was impossible.  1.5 hours though, it was the perfect time to get there, get the subs, and eat the way home. It was worth it though.  

My only gripe is that the people are some of the meanest I've had. Not realyl sure what they're pissed about.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Just an expensive sandwich place with a very long line.  Hard to compare to the amazing true deli's in NY or even on the Hayes.

Nothing exciting or even that good.  Whatever.

I live a half a block from this place and have gone twice in three years.....  Boring for sure....   I can make this at home better.
author: Cristof E.

description:
Delicious, but for your own sanity, call ahead on a weekend.

Oh, and mayo and mustard are on everything, as well as a "secret" italian sauce.  I love the Italian, no mayo or mustard, extra sauce.
author: Rachel W.

description:
You need to go here just to watch the guy slice an avocado.  He is an artist.  

The sandwiches are okay, not amazing, but definitely good.  Oh, and a large is indeed a large.  No skimping on size here.
author: Paul L.

description: Okay so I'm totally not a sandwich person (booring!) but these are so freakin good I'll sometimes drive from Fremont and back just for these morsels of heaven.  The bread is perfectly toasted -- not too much not too little -- the cheese melted just right, the salami (or other cold cut) delicious.  Oh and don't forget the special (vinaigrette-type) sauce.  It's taken me a long time to Yelp Marina Subs cuz I don't really want this Bay Area secret to get out.  I don't want to have to wait behind long lines getting teased by the divine aroma.  So don't go.  Please.
author: Ann H.

description:
How many avocados do you think Q has sliced in his lifetime? 10 million? This guy is ridiculous - pretty much the best sandwich in town. I will drive all of the way across town to eat there. Tip to the wise - always call in your order (EVEN IF YOU ARE STANDING IN LINE). He alternates making sandwiches between one phone and one in-person order. 

Also - I don't think I have ever seen the same stoner work the register twice (and I have been there over 40 times) .
author: Angie L.

description:
ooookkkkkkk....... so, i work in the neighborhood and have been here several times. the sandwiches are good, but nothing spectacular. he uses good ingredients, and will toast your sandwich if you like, but my main complaint about this place is about the customer service. 

firstly, there's usually a huge line, so calling ahead is always a good idea. but if you do decide to just walk in and order, you must know EXACTLY what you want because the owner, the one that actually makes the sandwiches, has 0% patience. it's like your being in the business is a major imposition on him. i was in there today for a sandwich and gave my order specifically and to the point, and he was still rude. 

i don't care how mad your avocado cutting skills are. be nice! -_- 

definitely had my last sub sandwich from Marina Subs today. guess i'll just stick to the new Irish Bakery in the neighborhood. at least they smile when you walk in...
author: Sherah M.

description: My first visit here convinced me that this was one of the best sandwich places in SF. I loved the soft toasted bread, meat, and LOADS of AVOCADOS. The man sure knows how to make his sandwich. The sauce, Italian dressing, gives the sandwich a little UMPH but shouldn't be the reason this place is getting anymore than four stars. After a few more visits, i start realizing how my sandwich easily gets soggy fast and begin to think about what exactly i like about the sandwich. it's a great place to get a sandwich, but its not something we can't all make at home.
author: Connie C.

description: Great local spot. Menu is simple. The servings are generous and fairly priced!!
author: Bill H.

description:
This place is a classic deli spot with sandwiches that are greater than the sum of its parts. For some reason, if I were to have the same exact items (meats, cheese etc.) at my disposal, I could not come close to producing a sandwich as delicous as the ones served.

Minus a star for the absurdly long waits, but the phone-in order is a blessing.

While normal sandwiches are definately 4 star at least, don't be shy go for the meatball sub or atomic sub which is a 5 star party.

Have to stress the call in again.
author: Mark B.

description:
Great, totally enormous sandwhich's prepared by a man with some of the best knife skills I have ever seen.  Total avocado slicing magic, I watched in amazement for like 20 minutes.  Takes forever though, so call ahead!

The owner won't let anyone else make sandwhiches,  and he has been doing it for years,  so you know the bar is high.  The guy manning the counter is not super helpful,  but who cares, food rocks,  just call ahead, and enjoy the avocado slicing entertainment.
author: Chris M.

description: Amazing, warm with avocado and turkey...couldn't ask for anything better
author: Jenny I.

description:
Yum yum yum! SO MUCH avocado! best sandwich place in the marina.  
very (very) long line and cash only.
author: She-ra Princess of power M.

description:
I've been going to Marina Submarine for over twenty years (I think), and not one single thing has changed. That is definitely a good thing. I'm biased, since I grew up only a few blocks away, but I can not think of a place at which I'd rather eat lunch. I know other people have mentioned it, but you must get avocado on your (hot pastrami) sandwich, if only to watch Q dispatch two entire avos onto your sandwich in about five seconds. 
It's pretty funny how he always has a new kid at the register, struggling to keep up. 
I really can't use enough superlatives to describe Q's sandwich making ability, so I will say only that Q is the undisputed sandwich master, his supremacy unquestionable!
If the line is long, wait. It's worth it. And don't complain. He's doing it all himself!
author: CM C.

description:
is it me, or is the Asian guy kind of off? he smiles and looks around but doesn't say much and his response time seems a bit slow. people say his knife skills are amazing however if you've ever worked in a restaurant then i'm sure you've seen those same knife skills time and time again. i remain unimpressed.

it's a plus that the sandwiches are heavy and heated, however there is nothing special there. the "secret sauce" is italian dressing, i'm quite sure. and what's with no bread options? i only saw the french bread and sliced wheat....whaddup??
author: Regina C.

description:
If you're craving a heart attack on a Colombo roll, this is the place to be (and an atomic sub the sandwich to order). To be honest, I haven't been here in a few years, but my high school was nearby and these sandwiches went well with cheap beer. 

The sandwiches are good, but that's about it. I wouldn't call them the best in the city, but I'll always hold a soft spot for the place because of the sheer volume of sandwiches I've had there and the good times we had trying to scarf down an atomic sub during lunch break. Plus, I always loved the fact that the often grumpy owner would smile and make my order automatically. Makes you feel special. Also makes you think he'd call 911 for you when your artery clogs. That's a full service sandwich shop right there.

check it out if you're in the area, but only die-hard regulars and old fans need drive across town for it. If you're not nearby, check out Captain Sub, or Submarine Center. Good eatin'
author: Mitchell L.

description:
Good times, and not the 'good times' that you say in awkward silences, but the kind that adam corolla would say right before girls jumpping on trampolines, GOOD TIMES. 

you better bring chash cuz they dont take the plastic. (said face)
author: David P.

description: Get the turkey, avocado, and cheese sandwich with EVERYTHING.  Honestly.  You are going to be waiting in a long line for what will feel like forever because it probably will be forever considering there is only one guy who makes the sandwiches. Granted he is a master at  it (take a look when he is cutting the avocado up...) so i don't blame him.  But as I was saying.. you will be waiting in a line forever and you will be staring at the menu changing your mind a million times. If it is your first time then take it the safe way and just do the turkey.  Don't forget to get a pickle... sooo good.  And then, once you have taken the plunge then start to venture out into the amazing menu.  Or have it your way and start with the italiano or even the atomic.  you will be back.. I know I will
author: Kylie L.
