description: I could for real watch this guy cut  avocados all day long.  I am shocked that he has all 10 fingers!!!  Moving on, the subs are incredible as well.  Unfortunately, a lot of people know that, so there is often a wait.  I would suggest trying to come at an off hour (i.e. not during lunch), or call ahead (if you can get through- I have tried this and failed).  But the subs are definitely worth the wait.
author: Nora S.

description: Best of neighborhood by far.  It just takes too damn long.  Not because I'm impatient, but anyone can see how inefficiently the place is run.  You must ask yourself honestly, is it worth spending 15 minutes of my lunch break in line for the reward of delicious flavor?  Sometimes yes, sometimes no.  When yes, I never regret the decision.
author: Ian S.

description:
Seriously Q....get some help back there.  I waited 30+ minutes for a mediocre meatball sub (that he burnt)...

Currently on my blacklist.
author: Joseph A.

description: BEST subs in the city. if you go during lunch hours you can for sure expect a line. sometimes a bit more expensive than usual but the way they toast the sub is incredible. if im EVER in the area, i have to stop by this spot. they also have a small gelato ice cream happening too. never had it but i guess its a nice perk to the place. i highly suggest going out of your way to give this spot a try. i been going here for 15 or so years and it only gets better as the time goes on...
author: Andrew D.

description:
Let me start by saying the sub is good.  I'll actually say pretty damn good.  However, it is not at all worth the 25 minute wait.  Honestly, people will exaggerate and say 45 minutes, an hour - whatever.  But 25 minutes is a real, honest estimate of how long it will take to get your sandwich.  15 people in line?  25 minutes.  Only person in the store?  25 minute wait.  Call ahead an hour before you arrive?  25 minute wait.

I have been to places that are outstanding and I'd wait all day for what they've got.  But this ain't it.
author: Kevin M.

description: This is hands down one of my favorite sub-sandwich shops in the city.
author: Michael A.

description: I was attracted to this sandwich shop by the smell ... it smelled like heaven ! I thought the sandwiches would taste like a piece of heaven too but boy was I disappointed ! I got the submarine sandwich ... it was too salty ! But other than that , it tasted ok but nothing special about it .
author: Eileen L.

description:
this is strictly a pickle review...you heard it right, a review about a pickle.  i love me a good, vinegary, whole dill pickle...so to my delight, this place sells them for a dollar.  now, i know i'm just noshing on a cucumber, but whoever created the first pickle is a genius and i can't thank you enough.  it was just the best thing to walk into a sandwich shop, so my friend could buy herself a sandwich, and find that i could get a beautiful, green treat myself.

only one star off for building the anticipation on getting my pickle, as my purchase was not communicated from the cashier to the sandwich maker.
author: Marjie T.

description: Even my hipster friends who avoid the Marina like it's the plague (the kind that's hidden under the designer jeans of the typical Marina Bro) are willing to make the trek to Marina Submarine for a sando conjured up by the Wizard of the Delimeat. Yeah, you're gonna wait longer than you'd like. Sure, you may pay a little more you think is reasonable. But once you hone your snake-like ability to unhinge your jaw and take that first massive bite, you're gonna forget about your qualms and find yourself in Tasty'n'Toastyland, and you'll never want to leave.
author: Anna K.

description: Possibly the best toasted subs in the City. Call ahead to avoid the wait.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Ok, so I did not know the "call ahead" rule and waited in anguish for over AN HOUR for this sub. I kept wanting to ditch to go somewhere else, but the other half of me kept saying- no no, this will be worth it- check out those avocado skills. 

I think the worst part of the stand still line in the dinky shop was watching his assistant just stand there not making subs. Let the guy help make a sandwich!! I seriosuly was half laughing and half crying watching the painful process. 

So, an hour and about $40 later (chips, waters) we took our 3 turkey-avocado subs to Muir Woods. Little did I also know that you have to order your sauce on the side. We were left with soggy, sloppy processed turkey sandwiches and had no choice but to take 2 bites and toss them in the compost, as they were already 3/4 disengrated with sauce and avocado mush. 

I will stick with my real italian subs at Lucca's Deli thank you very much.
author: Rena Z.

description: Always great, never dissapointed unless they run  out of pastrami
author: Michael B.

description: THis is really the only true east coast sub I have found in the city. Honestly. I'm sure there are others, but when you are craving that shredded lettuce-thinly sliced onion-italian dressing and mayo taste, there's just no beating this place. Call ahead (but not too far ahead or your sandwich will be soggy when you get it) because the lines are long. But this place is sooooooooo worth it.
author: Sbicy Meatball J.

description: I tried Marina Submarine for the first time and it was awesome!  Kyu was super friendly and gave my puppy some snacks.  It was indeed amazing to watch him slice avocados up -- if you love avocado, this is your place.  The sandwiches don't seem to be anything special, but they are surprisingly delicious.  I wish I knew what the ingredients/allergens were in the sandwiches were.
author: Tony G.

description: Although it can take 15 minutes to get a sandwich at times, it is well worth the wait.  The sandwiches are simple but delicious.  It is worth ordering avocado on your sandwich just to watch the guy cut it up so quickly.  If you are going around lunchtime, i would call the order in.
author: Robert R.

description: If anyone remember the Seinfeld episode with the soup Nazi you will only appreciate this place more. Hands down the Sub Nazi resides at this restaurant. The man is an animal. No one touches the sammy's besides him. There is always a line, a line worth waiting in. If you have the courage to call ahead of time go for it, but I sense the Sub Nazi is not a huge fan of those who call in. The turkey avocado is superb. Get the bread toasted, you can't go wrong with this sammy. If you are starving you can always grab a bag of chips to snack on as you wait. I give props to the young kid who rings you up. I bet he is scared to death of the Sub Nazi but he comes back everyday for more.
author: Jen B.

description: Overall pretty good. Subs take a really long to make (20+ minutes), the rolls end up pretty soggy but the meats are really good. My bf is from New York and he is all about "the perfect sandwich" and he says we need to try this place one more time in order to give it a fair review. So, more to follow.
author: Megan L.

description:
goodness, this torpedo of a sandwich was HUGE. but lucky for them, i had a manly appetite after rock climbing.

their "small" may look small in length but the chef really packs it in. to fold it in half, he has to jam his knife blade in to fold it. i would recommend ordering avocados just to watch the chef slice and dice it. he'll also put an avocado and a half or something into your sandwich, so if you're not a fan of heavy amts, dont do it. 

unfortunately for me, my friends ordered the last of the roast beef, so i asked the chef for suggestions. he started building my sandwich and handed me a fatty vegetarian sandwich with avocados. it was good, but avocado overload! There was a lot of juice from the veggies spewing out everywhere, causing a huge mess on my hands and on the table. i have yet to learn how to master handling my torpedos.

i still finished it though. A+ for me!

I'd come here for if you're in the area and  looking for a nice hefty sandwich.
author: Rena Y.

description:
My husband is from Sausalito and went to school in San Francisco up the street from Marina Subs.  I think he spent every after school day here getting the Submarine sandwich.  So he has been going here for 25ish years and when we go to visit we end up here everytime.
I think this place is great for the type of sandwich they serve.  Dont expect something gourmet.  It is a sub sandwich and I wouldnt say the meats are the best quality and in fact I have heard the owner actually say that the Pastrami might be a little fatty to a girl ordering it in front of me this past trip.
You will wait in line
It does take the guy a long time because he does make every sandwich, but I have NEVER seen him go from taking money to making a sandwich and I have been there many times.  He has a dedicated cashier/drink getter.
This is just one of those places where either you get it or you dont.  But you have to try to find out.
author: C W.

description: I used to eat here a fair amount as a kid. While I'm not as crazy about this place as my brother is, it's still a really good sub.
author: Erik S.

description: Maybe the subs are good, I don't know.  We waited in line for literally 35 minutes before leaving because we hadn't moved and there were still four people in front of us.  Guys kept taking phone orders ahead of the people in the shop which is bunk.
author: Michael N.

description:
Let's see...you wait forever, the prices are a little high for a sandwich, parking sucks, decor is dreary.  What does this all add up to?  A wonderful, tasty place -- maybe the best -- to grab a hot sandwich in SF.  The reason why one can overlook all the negatives is the owner, a real character with an insane memory (he remembers his customers, including their orders) and a crazy ability to chop avocados.  He serves up enormous subs with loads of toppings, all toasted to perfection.  I love the cheese sub (medium) plus avocado.  Don't get the avocado sandwich, however, b/c you'll end up with no fewer than two full avocados on your bread -- which I find to be a little too much.  The Italiano is a favorite among the carnivores.

Bottom Line: bring a magazine to read while in line and prepare to eat a sandwich so great, you won't need to eat for the rest of the day!
author: L G.

description:
I have been going here for 24 years and have been known to drive across the bridge just to a cheese sub(became an ovo-lacto veg along the way- I used to get Turkey and cheese).  If you are not going for cheese and the special sauce you are not getting the whole experience - I suspect those who score this place lower did not.  

Please note - they are best eaten hot - within minutes is the best.  Do not forget the extra napkins and be prepared to wait if it is lunch time.
author: J M.

description: I don't come here often cause the wait/line is redonkulous, at all hours. But today I had patience and all kinds of time and I wanted a great sando.  The toasted turkey, provolone, tons of lettuce lots of fresh tomato, onion, little jalapeno, little sauce made my afternoon, and eased me into my unanticipated "break" from the workforce. The owner does runs a tight ship and doesn't take attitude, he is the only one who makes the sandos, a master, he is!
author: Sarah B.

description: Good size mated to great flavor and a very apparent focus on perfection on the part of the sandwich maker.  He's the only one making sandwiches so be patient and you'll be rewarded with a solid sub that will stick to your ribs.  Hit him up off peak hours and you'll have far faster service (of course).  And for those who are wondering... this place and that other place in West Portal have been around for years.  I love this place.
author: A D.

description: Good teriyaki sub, but calling ahead is a must or just having really good timing.  Guy cuts an avocado like nobody's business.
author: Will A.

description:
I'm biased here as I have been going to this place for about 15 years now but this is the best sandwich shop in the city. You can tell where natives grew up in the city if they are sub fans because most of them either side with Marina subs or that other unspeakable (yet delicious) place in Portola. My bro went to SI and we have arguments about this all the time. 

No you cannot eat off the floor and no you cannot get a sandwich on dutch crunch. This isn't a deli. It's a sub shop that's incredibly busy and a great value in an expensive area.

The rumored, and likely, reason there is "only one guy" who makes the sandwiches is that he had guys who worked for him and then they ripped off the recipes, setup and suppliers and started their own place in competition with him. I have no idea if this is true, but it appears to be. You'd be gun shy too.

Frankly, I like the wait and the cash only. It keeps those who don't really appreciate the sandwiches out. The place is too popular to bother with those who don't get it. 

If you're in a hurry there's a taco bell/kfc 4 blocks away just for you. Please, partake!
author: SF P.

description:
Marina Submarine makes a FAT sandwich.   

So I ordered a sub with avocado and sprouts and Tony proceeded to slice 3 whole avocados for my sandwich.

That is pure generosity.  The toasted roll tasted great too.  

I like to get avocado with sprouts and tomato.  Delicious.  Based on this sandwich alone I'd vote Marina Sub the best vegetarian restaurant within a 10 minute walk of Union street.
author: Matt M.

description: Pretend you know  Q, yeah, you think you know him, but you dont.. well not as long as me and the other REAL city kids do. Dont ask for "special sauce" youre a punk, AND not a local. My bro who is damn near 15 years older than me went here after school as a kid, and I damn well followed in his footsteps. best damn meatball in town, plus I get my personal favorite, turkey, swiss, let, tom, avacado and sauce. toasted. beat that bitches
author: Liz C.

description:
What can I say that hasn't been said yet?
I've been coming here since 2000.
Medium turkey, avocado, and provolone. Orangina.
I've strayed away from "the usual" a few times over the years, but I always go back.
Also, few things are better than watching Q slice an avocado.
author: Enrique S.

description: I could eat one of these sandwich's everyday!!! I love them! turkey, provelone, lettuce, tomato, onion and SAUCE! Be sure and call it in if you can. It goes so much faster than waiting there, especially on the weekends. Don't upset the sandwich nazi. NO SANDWICH FOR YOU!
author: michelle k.

description: Best Sandwich Ever.  Well at least in the city.  Yes, you'll have to wait but come on... I just said it's the best sandwich in the city.  It's totally worth the wait.   Turkey, cheese, avocado is my thing but I also dabble in the teriyaki chicken.  Having this place a block away from my apartment was pretty much why I chose to live in that apartment.   SO  good, you guys.
author: Jacquie M.

description: I must start this off telling you that I am a frequent buyer...or would I say eater....at Roxie's Sandwiches...YUM!  However, my boyfriend and I were in the Marina earlier today and starvation was on the brink!  After hearing about the rival sandwich shop for so long, we decided to try it out.  It was about 11:00am when we got there, so it was empty, except for the gentleman behind the counter, whom I'm going to assume was the owner.  He was very polite and friendly.  I ordered the meatball sub (I was hung over and a healthy sandwich was NOT gonna do it), my BF ordered the roast beef.  They were both delicious.  Lots of meatballs and a ton of cheese...just how I like it...I can't stand when places skimp you on the cheese.  The Roast Beef sandwich was also great...The best part of the roast beef sandwich was the fact that he put an entire avocado on there!  My bf was sold!!  He's kind of obsessed with Avocado's, I think he's actually on the verge of turning green, LOL.  Either way, we ordered 2 sandwiches, 3 bags of chips, 2 orangina's and 2 Stella's all of which came out to $32.60.  Not bad...not bad at all.  My only complaint would that there wasn't bread options available, I think the Roast Beef would have been better on Dutch Crunch bread...like Roxie's does :)  Oh...and FYI, they're cash only
author: Ashley J.

description: Sandwich Ninja Rocks. Call in your order to avoid line if you going between 1145 and 1245. Everything is good, pastrami is best pastrami I ever tasted, thick and lean. Meatballs are good too.
author: auclair k.

description:
I guess I didn't exercise my face off or wait in a long line to reach the same level of complacency of a lot of these yelpers.

I had the special sauce (italian dressing) and italian sub. It was your regular mass produced salami meats and provolone cheese atop Subway-style pink tomatoes and shredded iceberg lettuce. 

It's a decent sandwich. To be fair, it's a lot better than Subway. But for those who say it's the best sub in the city, there must be a bunch of shitty subs out there. 

If you want a good sandwich, I recommend La Spiaggia Delicatessen.
author: ascheras g.

description: This is by far my favorite sandwich place, EVER! A friend introduced it to me a few years ago and I am hooked! I love that the only person who makes your sandwich is this old Asian guy who really doesn't say much. If you like HUGE portions than this is the place for you! The sandwiches are so full of toppings and oozing with the sauce...its to die for, really I'm drooling now! If you like avocado, get it, you won't be disappointed, they are always the best avos and he puts an entire one on each sandwich, even the littlest ones! I could talk about this place for days...only downside is with one guy working the line can get a bit long, but its worth it...you can also put in phone orders FYI! PS. they only take cash!
author: Katie W.

description: Good sandwiches, the bread is all toasty and warm, plus its the cheapest place to get lunch on union (that I have found). I didn't like the kid behind the counter, he rushed me, and i was spaced out b/c I had to take lunch 3 hours late, and then he kept making assumptions about what I wanted, like I wanted a small, or I wouldn't like the sandwich with a whole sausage in it. So i got a large and ate the whole thing. I also like how they just slam your sandwich on some paper instead of wrapping it up, what's the point of wrapping it anyway? they have beer too, for those not on lunch break, or those who like to live on the edge! -1 star for the kid who didnt think I could eat.
author: Natalie K.

description: Good taste & value; you get an entire avacado, sliced, for $1.  Not the fanciest digs, but good enough. And the Benni-Hanna-like knife skills are always entertaining.
author: Michael L.

description: Been going here since I was a little girl... if you grew up in SF, chances are, you used to hang out here all the time too.  Sandwiches are great... hot crispy bread dripping with secret sauce.  Get ready to wait in line for a while though...
author: Mary S.

description: Great sandos although they're staff could use a little "DSL" because they have a severe case of the "slowsky's"...man they move slow there.  Step it up - I'm definitely not that patient.
author: Danielle V.

description: This is my favorite sandwich shop in all of San Francisco.  Q gives you an amazing amount of high quality food for the price.  Be sure to call in your order during rush hour.
author: John G.

description:
I love this place. Yes, the line is long, but it's worth it. 

Get a sub with special sauce.
author: j c.

description: The italino is the best sanwich I have had in a while.  I cannot speak for any other sandwich, because I loved that one and have not tried any others.
author: Tim J.

description: Best subs in the City bar none. Wait time is a big problem but easily solved by calling 15 minutes in advance with your order. Portions are way too big for me so the wife and I normally share a medium Italiano, but if you plan your demand timeline you can't get a better sandwich in the City.
author: David J.

description:
I used to love these subs. And I figured out how to bypass the ridiculous lines by phoning in my order to the pimple-faced kid about 20 minutes before going to the shop.

And then I got violently ill after snarfing one. I asked my friends who also dine there and two of them copped to booting up a grinder. Not sure if it's the meat or the mayo... but it's definitely Marina Sub. 

Anyone else have an unexplained purge after downing one of these beauties?
author: Bill K.

description: Q, or Tony as he is known to his American compatriots, has spent nearly 30 years as a Sandwich Artist. And I don't mean the employees in green polos at Subway, this guy is a master of his craft. I practically grew up in this hoagie haven, skating down after class at 3 to grab a turkey sub before B-Ball practice. Tony's probably made over 1 million sandwiches, but I dare someone to actually try and calculate. Try the Cheesesteak with jalapenos or the Italiano. Or you can always go for the good old Turkey, Swiss and Avo. Whats in the secret sauce you may ask? He's not telling.
author: Sam S.

description: Oh. my. god.  HUGEST and TASTIEST subs ever.  Tons of all the good stuff- (pickles, tomatoes, meat cheese and ooh the sub vinaigrette.  Awesome) not to mention watching the guy making them is very entertaining.  He moves faster than most people working in the ER.  Pretty cheap but it gets busy - don't go in right at 12 or it'll be a minute. Cash only (duh).
author: Allison C.

description: I have been going to this place since freshman year of high school and it possibly has the best subs. Everything is fresh and tastes wonderful. Whenever my friends come to visit I always take them to this place and they adore it. It is a cute neighborhood spot to pick up a nice lunch. I would recommend calling ahead of time if you know what you want and you go at a busy hour so that you don't have to wait in such a long line. Fantastic!
author: Elizabeth A.

description: Turkey and avacado on toasted bread? Yes please! Everything is so fresh!
author: Carson H.

description: I've lived in the area for 5 years and I just discovered this place.  Where have I been?  The wait can get to you but there are a few  ways you can entertain yourself while you wait.  1) watch the sandwich master chop avocados at the speed of light, and 2) comtemplate why the sidekick can't do more than ring up your order.
author: Kumar D.

description: This is one of my favorite sandwich places in the city. I love the marina sub. The owner is always present , and he whips out sandwiches like no tommorow. I like to secretly call him the " sub nazi". There is always a line, but worth the wait!!
author: Amy H.

description:
Oh Marina Sub! How do I love thee?  After over 30 years of coming here and ordering the same thing, I cannot count the ways. When I am away from you, I dream about you: the delicious tang of your "special" sauce, the chomp of your freshly Ginsu-ed pickle, the crunch of your freshly toasted bread, all mixing with the oooey gooey deliciousness of your oven melted cheese. (Excuse me for a moment while I change panties!) 
   As a San Francisco native I cut my teeth on these beautiful masterpieces and I feel very fortunate to have had the privilege.  I'm 36 now and I had my first ham and cheese at 2 1/2...you do the shameful math! 
   Sure, sometimes you'll get there and the line will be out the door, and yeah maybe it takes 20 minutes to get a sandwich on a really busy day, but it is all worth it just to watch a master at work.  Q is the uncontested master samurai of submarines. His knife skill are better than those of master chefs!  Order a pickle, even if you don't like them, just to watch him slice and you'll know what I'm talking about. As the self proclaimed ambassador of my hometown I have brought every visitor I have ever had from every corner imaginable of the world to Marina Sub, and they all proclaim through greedy mouthfuls that Marina Sub is the proverbial s**t.  Thank you, Q, for bringing this wonderful gift in the form of a sub into my life.  My heavenly constant, you always guide me to satisfaction!
Tips: You can order ahead over the phone, but I don't like to do this as timing is everything with a sub.  Leave it 5 minutes too long on the counter and the bread won't have the warmth and crunch that is so satisfying. Do yourself a favor and grab the two seater in the window, watch the yuppies go by while you wait, and strap yourself in to be transported to the heavenly ninth wonder that is Marina Sub.
The only con: It doesn't stay open later!  I need my fix!
author: PieTheSwingCat T.

description: Best place a 12 years old kids ever introduced me to.Serious size sandwich and I swear that I wouldn't strayed from Yellow sub and Ted's market but LORD HAVE MERCY!!! I have my weakness and I know that sandwich god will forgive me for this.Their sandwiches will be the end of me.SIGH.......
author: S F.

description: Great sandwiches, walking distance...jesus I want one right now.
author: Mike T.

description: best sandwich i've had in san francisco. normally i get a medium pastrami or original sub. with everything and avocado! doesn't matter if you eat it there or take it to go the sandwich will not get soggy w/ the special sauce! Best way to order is if you call in your order!
author: Bruce L.

description: I am addicted to these subs!  I love them.  The avocado on any sando  is out of this world.  FYI...it may be slow, but art takes TIME!  The chef is a true master.  It's fun to watch him create these masterpieces!!   Yum yum yum my mouth is watering just thinking about a medium turkey avo w/ jalepenos.  I think I am going to get one NOW!
author: Chris P.

description: I love the subs at this place!!!!anything you get will be sooooo good. you do have to wait a while. they are VERY $$$$$ its like $8.00 for a small sub and small drink! you have to really save up for this.lol but its almost worth it I have to say..besides the fact the asian guy who makes the subs I dont think he likes women very much so watch out.
author: LoLa L.

description: Maybe I just ordered wrong, but the turkey and swiss sandwich I got here was served on a soggy hoagie roll that had no taste.  In fact, the only taste there was was the mustard.  The deli meats looked and tasted like they came out of one of those watery packages like you'd get a cheap deli.  Like I said, maybe I ordered wrong, but I don't understand all the hype about this place.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Quirky, quick, and delicous.  I often worry that the poor kids running the register are being abused- the sandwich guy won't let them even come NEAR a sandwich or even the sandwich-making area!!  They seem happy enough, probably because they are plied regularly with sandwiches...
author: Alison R.

description: SO GOOD! Quick service, you can call ahead and have a hot, grilled sub sandwich ready for pick-up in 10 minutes. Comes in small and large (small is pretty big, large is truly ambitious). My boyfriend introduced me to this place a couple years ago, but he and his friends have been going since high school.
author: Christy M.

description: These are great simple subs. The servings are large. By far my favorite is the turkey & avocado. It comes with a whole fresh cut avocado...delicious. The line can be a bit long at lunch on the weekdays so call ahead your order.
author: Tyler S.

description: Although the wait is kinda painful when you are hungry, and your food can take a long time to get to you it is worth the wait.  Although they put an entire avocado on my cheese sandwich which was a little too much, the combo of the melted cheese, fresh avocado, "special dressing" and perfectly toasted roll was really really really good.  I would definetly recommend it, but not if you are in a hurry.
author: Jennie J.

description: I have not found a better submarine.  I don't really like rating 5 stars, but I love this place.  The old guy making sandwiches is not very social, but he makes great stuff.  I have been to Roxy, Yellow submarine, Sub Station...still, not a better sub yet.  Get the small unless you eat a lot.  I am 6 ft, 190, and eat for two most of the time.  A small sandwich is perfect for lunch.
author: Kapeli M.

description: I just saw a man put five avocado halves on one sandwich. I'm pretty simple. There's a positive linear correlation between the amount of cheese/avocado on something and my rating. But yes, the wait does suck, which led us to tear into chips while waiting in line. A good solution if you're a compulsive eater like me. Don't even think about going if you have anywhere to be in the next hour or two. Worth the price because you probably won't finish it.
author: Katie T.

description: This is one of the best places in the city to get an amazing sandwich.   They are huge and you have to get the sauce.  So good.  Anytime I'm working in the Marina I make sure that I stop here.  The owner is always nice and takes great care in your sandwich.  But you have to be careful later in the afternoon because sometimes its just suddenly closed.  Also it's cash only!
author: Julia E.

description:
You're kidding, right? You must be kidding. 

So I used to live in the Marina years ago and I would come here from time to time. I remembered it being good. So when my boyfriend had a hunkering for a sub, I suggested this place. Mind you I was kind of starving, as in I could eat my own arm after running 6 miles that morning. So I figured a sub place is perfect, fast and quick. Right??? WRONG!
We find a parking space right out front (amazing!) Then we see a line. I mean nothing crazy but maybe 6 people, so I figure, "Crap. I'm not gonna get my freakin' sandwich for like 15 minutes. And I want to eat NOW!" Boy was I wrong. I stood in line for exactly 1 hour. Yes 60 minutes, count them!!! By the time 20 minutes passed, I was too invested to leave. 
I proceeded to sigh loudly, look around, shift from foot to foot, clench my fists, utter obscenities under my breath, and then contemplate what my arm would really taste like. Then I proceeded to be a bitch to my boyfriend taking out my frustrations on him. An hour and 30 minutes later, I finally put this sandwich in mouth thinking by now anything would taste good. And it wasn't even all that. Kinda bland.  WTF?!?
Basically this place wasted two of my hours on a nice sunny day, made my stomach eat itself out of desperation, made my boyfriend and I cross with each other, and ultimately made my boyfriend sick with a stomache (stomach + ache= stomache). I hate this place. It ruined my day. 
And don't even get me started on the two 13 year olds standing behind the counter doing absolutely nothing while the old asian man was ready to have a heart attack making 76 sandwiches. Don't get me wrong, I don't hate that poor old asian man for ruining my day, just for the poor management of the place and the line. Not even an apology was uttered.
author: Jessica W.

description:
gigantic subamarine sandwiches.

gigantic.
sandwiches.

the sandwich artist is very generous with the slices of meat, cheese, avocado, etc. 

speaking of avocado, i would like to go back and watch his slicing technique. it usually takes me a good 8 minutes to slice these babies.
author: Rosalee C.

description: It's worth the wait.  Fresh ingredients, HUGE portions, toasted perfectly!  Definitely get the avocado, and definitely call it in if you can.  If you are starving and have to wait a half hour, have some chips in line while you watch the owner kick some serious sandwich ass.  Never disappoints.
author: Em S.

description: I was debating whether it's a four or three star.  Gave it a four because I just tried Lucca Delicatessen and think the sandwich here is slightly better.  We had a company lunch and I had half turky and half chicken.  The chicken sandwich is totally not what I expected.  I was expecting a whole piece 100% chicken breast, instead was some chopped up processed, frozen ,Tyson brand type of chicken.  I mean it's not terrible but just totally unexpected.  The turkey on the other hand was much better.  Very juicy sandwich on some soft roll with the usual sandwich fixings.  This place is worth a try if you happen to be in the area and craving for sandwiches.  By the way, the sandwich is huge and cost about $6.00.
author: Heidi F.

description: This place is extremely overrated. The sandwiches are decent, but do not justify the price at all. Okay, yeah, they give you a lot of avocado, but guess what, so do a lot of places. The wait time here is ridiculous. I'm willing to wait for a quality meal, but 40 minutes is beyond excessive. I don't really understand why the owner can't hire someone to help him make the sandwiches, instead of just having a cashier. Also, charging 45 cents for cheese is bullshit when the sandwich itself already costs $6.50. Overall, a big disappointment and not worth it in any respect.
author: Aly S.

description: This place is pretty good. I used to get really excited about going here like 6 years ago. The sandwitchs are all heated and have an italian kinda dressing on them in which was kinda tart. I had to wait like 20 minutes though! Geez. Great sandwitch place. If you like Submarine Center in west portal this is place is its snobbier sister.
author: Tiffany D.

description: I have one thing to say- I went in to grab a quick sandwich with a few buddies. There were four people in front of us, no biggie, that's what anyone normal would think. AND THEN, 45 minutes later we are just about to order our sandwich. The most horrible service I have ever experienced. I will never go there again. They put the phone orders ahead of humans and they dont even look at you when you are ordering your sub. And lastly, there is only one person working. Did i mention it took 45 minutes to get a sandwich....which was just, okay.
author: Nedda T.

description: May look like a dive, but this place has the best subs in town.  They toast the rolls and use fresh meat and veggies.  There is usually a line, so don't go if you're in a huge rush.  The owner makes all of the subs himself (hence the long line) and usually has some high school kid helping wrap the subs and work the register.  Certainly say YES when asked if you want the "special sauce"...it's what makes these subs so good.
author: Kala H.

description:
Marina Subs is great if you call ahead and order your sandwich.  The best thing is that they put a whole avocado on your sandwich.  

They have a huge line if you don't call in, so I highly recommend it becuase the 1 guy who makes them takes call in orders before the line in the shop.
author: vikki a.

description: The special sauce is good, the bread is nice, and the avocado is always fresh. Only one person (Tony I think) is allowed to make the sandwiches, so the line can get ridiculous. The trick is to order over the phone and pickup.
author: Hurston P.

description: Really good quality sandwich shoppe. They're a touch on the greasy side because of all of the deliciousness they lay on your sando, but the bread is always perfectly toasted, the meat is boar's head brand, so you're not eating filler, and the price is dead on. Oh, and the guy that runs the place has a freakishly good memory...after only going a handful of times he already knew what I liked, and started making my sandwich before I even told him what I wanted.
author: Gary S.

description: I used to go to catholic school right around the corner from this place and this was actually my first job out of high school so I've literally eaten hundreds of these sandwiches. I can honestly say these are the best subs in the city. It's mostly because of the Columbo bread and the "special sauce". I'll never divulge the secret of the special sauce. Alright, it's italian dressing. Since I'm outing special sauces, Mc Donald's special sauce is thousand island dressing and the secret ingredient is salt. I feel as if a great weight has been lifted off my shoulders. Anyway, the place is run and owned by a Korean guy named Tony. Everyday Tony would go downstairs and take a nap in the afternoon for a few hours during which time I took the opportunity to smoke weed, do the crossword puzzle and invite my friends over to give away food. Best-job-EVER! I gained like 20 pounds while working there. Being high and alone in a sub shop is both good and bad. The only thing I don't like about the place is the Marina crowd but if you're really high you won't mind so much.
author: Josua P.

description: Ever since I was 5 years old, Marina Submarine has been my favorite sandwich joint in SF. I am pretty sure the same man owns the place and makes the sandwiches. Don't forget the special sauce. And, always get it toasted.
author: Alexis K.

description: My first trip to this place will certainly be my last.  This was the MOST inefficient restaurant I have ever been to.  There is 1 man making subs while another man works the register.  The problem is the man cannot make the subs fast enough to get people to the register, so the man at the register sits there doing nothing while the line piles out the door.  Not only that, but the sub maker has to make subs for phone in orders so people in front of his face have to sit and wait.  After waiting in like for 35 minutes at 2 pm on Sunday to get a sandwich I was able to get my sub.  I ordered to go.  I had turkey which was pedestrian and looked like it was bough pre sliced at Costco.  The secret sauce is no more than Italian dressing and the onions were gross and numerous.  I live only 4 blocks away, and when I got home to eat my sandwich was soaking wet and disgusting.  I agree with people that the sub maker does know how to work an avocado but everything else was awful.  I appreciate the loyal people who frequent this place, but I would never go back and you should not either.
author: Ross D.

description: amazing. these sandwiches are simply amazing. i was a little peeved that the long line moved so slowly and i was so hungry, but it was well worth the wait.  i guess its the guy who owns the place that makes the sandwiches, and well, he knows what he's doing. i think i had half an avocado on my small sub. so good! and the "secret sauce" that actually tastes just like italian dressing is really delicious and adds tons of flavor to the sandwich. the fact that they serve beer is also a big pluss.
author: Meredith B.

description: Addictive.  Meatball sub and Turkey, Cheese, Avocado (TCA) earn Olympic Gold.  Add 'hand-sliced' dill and Jalapeño to your TCA for a very nice compliment to a all-star sando.  It will get all over your face, extra napkins are a must. The mess is well worth it.  Having been all around the Bay area, its not even competitive. Chef / owner Q is in a class all his own. Be patient in line on weekends. The wait is justified.
author: Tom B.

description: Great Sandwiches, but definitely call your order in.  The line is always long and the owner is the only one that makes the sandwiches.  Kinda like the San Francisco version of Seinfelds soup nazi.  Its worth the wait too.
author: Dan V.

description: long wait. okay sandwich. feeling sick later.
author: selma s.

description: I love Marina Sub.   It's true, you should call ahead or risk waiting in line for at least 20 minutes during peak hours.  It's all worth it though.  Sandwiches are hot and tasty!!!  If you like avocado, this is your spot--there is no skimping on the delicious green fruit.  How can you not love this one man (and teenage helper) enterprise!
author: Laura D.

description: get the turkey sub with everything and add avocado. once he toasts that sucker up.... yummmy! large sandwiches but still cant beat Freddies.
author: Gordon L.

description: This guy is like the Seinfeld soup nazi of submarine sandwiches and that is why I like him.  Always the same dude making sandwiches, he moves at his own consistant pace and he is very matter of fact but oh-the sandwiches.  Toasted bread, meat and cheese, tons of veggies (if you order avacado be prepared to eat at least 1/2 of one) and that sauce - AMAZING!
author: Robert A.

description: I go here at least once a week. The line is often long, but the guy making the sandwiches is an absolute machine and the sandwiches are unbeatable. The portions are very generous -- a large sandwich is easily enough for two meals -- and the price is reasonable.
author: Gregory G.

description: Yes, it may be in the Marina. Yes, it may be a bit pricey. Yes, the parking is shit. And yes, you may have good reason to be about to click to the next sandwich joint on this website... But STOP! right there! if you want to taste the most mouth watering, juicy, completely goddamn ridiculous sandwich ever made. To quote Robert R. "It is worth ordering avocado on your sandwich just to watch the guy cut it up so quickly." Astute observation, but the "guy" you speak of is really no guy at all--he is a magical sorcerer from a parallel universe of spicy meats and secret sauces, who only works here on this planet because he lost a bet with his evil counterpart and interstellar rival (who can be found making sandwiches at Viking Submarine on Lombard in this small blink of time in the history of the universe)--so he is doomed to toil among the mortals on Earth for all eternity instead of riding around on hovercrafts and partaking in time-travel. And a nickel to the person who can tell me what the suit and number of the card stuck to the ceiling are.
author: Nicholas E.

description: Anyone who has grown up in Pac Heights or the Marina knows that this sandwich shop tops them all! Although Q might not say much behind that counter as he chops avocado faster than a western cowboy can sling a gun, but the sandwiches are truly glorious once you take your first bite. I would recommend the turkey with provolone, lettus, tomato, avocado, mustard, and extra sauce. mmmm OR the meatball. :)
author: Blair H.

description: If toasted fresh bread with melted cheese, stuffed full of avocado, sprouts, lettuce, tomato, cheese & mayo sounds good to you, then you will love this place. The sizes are really generous = 2.5 whole avocados in my medium sub!!! Will be going back regularly.
author: pb ..

description: This is seriously the best sandwhich - and I don't even dig sandwhiches that much usually.  Whatever dressing he uses is amazing - also you have to add the pickled peppers for a kick.  We had a hard time moving away because we miss this place and go back every trip!!!  The owner is so nice!  He comes out to greet my dogs and gives them little snacks...
author: Erin G.

description: I've got some respect for marina sub. Eaten there for YEARS, but mostly out of convenience. It's really just a knock off of the submarine center #1 and #2 (which are and were way better). The menus are exactly the same. The dude who runs the place closes WAY too early and the helpers he hires are not very efficient so the line tends to get out the door and around the corner. If you are looking for a good sandwich in this area I suggest going up the hill to Mayflower Market on Fillmore. They have money deli sandwiches with little to no wait and at an unbeatable price.
author: Victor H.

description: Q is awesome. He taught me all about selecting avocados and what months to buy Haas versus Chilean... If you want to really have fun at this place, be nice to Q. I like his philosophy on life - he likes making sandwiches when he wants to make sandwiches. When he doesn't, the place is closed!  This place is a labor of love.
author: Senor R.

description: first off let me say i have been going here since high school, that is more than 15 years. in that time the place has not changed and that is everything from decor to sandwiches. the only real differences are the young kid checking people out and the depth of the knife induced dent in the owner's cutting board. overall though the food is consistently good, especially if you like avocados. the guy who makes the sandwiches is generally no nonsense but sorta friendly. he cuts avocados like a machine and never lets anyone else make sandwiches. because of that the quality is consistent. this place is in my regular sandwich rotation.
author: A G.

description: most of the people who gave m.subs less than the five stars it deserves, don't understand the process of and history behind the shop. i, the help behind the counter many have deemed either incompetent or absolutely useless, will help clarify and enlighten.  call me incompetent, but it is the customers who don't know the workings of the shop and are wandering the place wide-eyed and lost who really prove themselves to be so.  obviously, there is only one person who actually makes the sandwiches, kiyu (not "q").  he makes them alone because another pair of hands would be unable to keep up or produce half as good of a sandwich. therefore, out of practicality and time constraints, he works alone. providing a more than sufficient amount of help, the other person behind the counter takes phone orders, pours drinks, works the cash register and has to deal with the bullshit the marina and hungry, irrational people have to offer.   the line gets so long because of the people who have yet to comprehend the concept of phone orders and that orders of six or more sandwiches holds it up and should be given in advance (at least half an hour in advance).  and to the complaints in regards to the phone orders not being ready and presented on a silver platter the minute they step into the store, we don't have the sandwich made at the exact time we say we will because most people come ten minutes after we tell them to and complain about a soggy sandwich. maybe had the first person who came in fifteen minutes late and complained about their soggy sandwich not been such an ass, we'd have everyone's sandwiches ready on time. if you're one of those people who know they're going to be in later than told, say it with me, "sauce on the side".  no where else will you find such a beautiful sandwich made with such simple ingredients - no need for bacon, spicy mustard, pepporcinis, grilled chicken or whatever else you spoiled people are putting on sandwiches these days. why did I choose to work at m.subs? because I love avocado, the sandwiches are borderline orgasmic and kiyu's company surpasses anyone else's. he's considered a little rough on the edges because he doesn't get on all fours for  every customer, but he loves what he does more than anyone else i know and loves his customers even more. he'll remember your face after seeing you once, and your exact sandwich after you order it twice. count your lucky stars that there's a place as great as this.
author: mai n.
